âI would like to talk about some of the resource development projects in the north of Western Australia which I visited during the break and to report to the Senate about how these projects are proceeding. First of all, I would like to say a little about the Ord River stage 2 development. The Western Australian and Northern Territory governments announced in April that a joint venture between Wesfarmers and the Marubeni Corporation had been awarded a contract to further evaluate the Ord stage 2 proposal. Wesfarmers, as many senators will know, is a significant Western Australian company with thousands of shareholders and headquarters in Western Australia. Wesfarmers will hold 80 per cent of the joint venture. It is a company with a very grand history of involvement in agriculture in Western Australia and it is appropriate that it should be involved in stage 2 of the Ord development.

speech.para: The other partner in the joint venture is the Marubeni Corporation, which is one of Japan's leading trading firms and has a great deal of experience in the sugar industry, particularly in the development of sugar mills and refineries. The proposal for the second stage of the Ord is for an investment of some $300 million in an export oriented, raw sugar industry which will produce 400,000 tons of raw sugar per year. It will include the establishment of a sugar mill and development of storage facilities near the port of Wyndham on the far north coast of Western Australia.

Under the plan, irrigated farmland in the Weaber, Knox Creek and Keep River plains will be developed to extend the Ord River scheme to nearly 65,000 hectares. This will take it over the border into the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory government has been involved in the awarding of the contract to Wesfarmers and the Marubeni Corporation, because the second stage of the Ord is going to bring great economic development to the Northern Territory as well as to the north of Western Australia.

It is proposed to set aside land for independent small farmers, thus allowing crop and land ownership diversity in this second stage development. The memorandum of understanding currently being discussed with the proponents is for a feasibility study of the project, so that all issues of controversy relating to the project can be dealt with. If the project is shown to be sound from a financial, economic, technical and environmental point of view, stage 2 will go ahead and this will lead to the development of a world scale sugar industry based around significant sugarcane plantings and a sugar mill on the Ord River.

This will, as I have said, bring major economic development to east Kimberley. It is anticipated there will be some 500 jobs created in the area during the construction phase and a further 170 permanent jobs when the sugar mill is established. In addition, there will be 550 seasonal jobs during harvest time on the sugar plantations and a further 1,200 jobs created in local service industries. Hopefully, some of those jobs will go to indigenous people. It is hoped that indigenous people will take up some of the farmland in the second stage of the Ord and that Aboriginal communities in the north will benefit from this development.

There will be new port and storage facilities at Wyndham and this will lead, in addition, to other jobs. The port of Wyndham will be greatly expanded. There will be dredging of the channel performed and much other infrastructure created in that townâwhich is one of the oldest towns in the north of Australia and which has gone through something of an economic recession in recent years with the closure of the meatworks there. So the development of stage 2 of the Ord will have a very strong and positive impact on the community of Kununurra and in Wyndham and the whole surrounding area of the north Kimberley, if it goes ahead.

Unfortunately, it is an ifâif it goes aheadâand the if, of course, is the question of native title. As it happens, there are three conflicting native title claims on the second stage of the Ord. It is a matter of great concern that, unless these claims are resolved, then this great project will be held up for who knows how longâperhaps many yearsâand this great development will not occur. I must say it is quite clear that if the development of Ord stage 2 is put on the backburner and deferred for years until the native title issues are resolved, the responsibility will lie with those on the opposition benches who blocked the passage of the government's native title legislation which would have enabled these claims to be resolved in a sensible and equitable way within a reasonable timeframe. If, in fact, this does not happen, then I am sure the people of Australia will know who to blame for it and they will certainly bear that in mind when they go to the polls, presumably in the latter part of this year.

Just for the information of the Senate, there have been no new land releases at Kununurra made in the town or surrounding areas since the introduction of the Native Title Act in 1993, other than a single farming blockâand that resulted in extensive litigation. A major residential subdivision involving 200 lots has been delayed due to the impact of native title. In addition, 22 light industrial lots, 10 horticultural lots, a commercial centre and a tourism site have not been able to go ahead due to the slow processes of the existing Native Title Act. As I have said, I am sure that the voters of Australia will bear these facts in mind when they go to the polls in the next federal election. It is quite clear that it is thanks to the opposition and the Democrats that developmentsâsuch as the Ord stage 2âhave been delayed and that many other similar developments around Australia will be similarly delayed because the government amendments did not pass through the Senate.

Two weeks ago, I visited Karratha and Dampier, where the Pilbara Development Commission informed me that in the next five years it is possible that some $20 billion of investment will be made in resource developments in that area. That is an enormous amount of money and it is going to be the major resource development area of Australia if those investments are made. The possible projects there include: expansion, by a factor of three times, of the liquefied natural gas projects off the north-west coast; the development of a petrochemical plant; and secondary downstream processing of iron oreâwhich has been a long-term objective of the Western Australian government and is something which we all, as Australians, should be encouraging to happen. We need to not just export iron ore but to develop it into other products and get some superadded benefit to this country from so doing. As I have said, it would seem that Karratha-Dampier is set to become one of the most important industrial areas of Australia, if all the projected development in the area goes ahead.

Again, I am sorry to say that one of the major hindrances to the success of these resource and energy developments has been, and is, native title. The frustration of those in the north was evident on my recent visit when the Shire of Roebourneâthe shire that covers Karratha and Dampierâinformed me that around 2,500 building sites for workers' homes are being held up due to native title.

The point is that unless accommodation can be built for the workers of these great projects they will become fly-in fly-out projects. That means that they will make almost no contribution to regional development, because fly-in fly-out means that workers come in for a period of two or four weeks and then they are flown back to Perth or to wherever they come from around Australia. They put no roots into the communities and make no contribution to the development of those communities.

So while these projects could go ahead without land being available for worker accommodation it would be at the cost of a contribution to regional development. Once again, we come back to the issue of native title and to the fact that the mechanism which might have resolved the blockage in the provision of land for workers' homes in this area has been caused by the failure of the opposition parties to pass the government's native title amendments. And if regional development suffers as a result of this failure to be able to provide homes for the workers in the Karratha-Dampier area, the voters of Australia, I am sure, will remember that the opposition and their compatriotsâthe Democrats and the Greensâare to blame for failing to pass the government's Native Title Act amendments.

talk.start.para: âRecent speculation about the possibility of a double dissolution raises the issue of the most appropriate method of allocating short- and long-term Senate places after an election of the full Senate. The constitution provides that senators should have six-year terms and that half the Senate should retire at each ordinary Senate election. In the event of a double dissolution under section 57 of the constitution, the ordinary rotation of senators is disturbed and, following the election, the Senate is required to divide itself into short- and long-term senators. Although the constitution requires the Senate to divide itself in this fashion, it leaves the method of division into the two classes at the discretion of the Senate itself.

speech.para: The Senate has had to consider the issue of the most appropriate method of allocating short- and long-term places on seven occasions: once after the first Commonwealth election and then on the six occasions following double dissolutions. Traditionally, the method that the Senate has settled upon has been to divide senators on the basis of the order in which they were elected.

After the first Commonwealth election in 1901, the Senate debated the most appropriate method of determining short- and long-term senators. Under the voting system used by most statesâthat is, single electorate block voting, which is effectively a winner-take-all systemâthe Senate was basically faced with two choices. The first was to follow the United States tradition of dividing senators into classes by lot. The second alternative was to allocate six-year terms to the three senators in each state who had been returned with the highest number of votesâand the Senate finally settled on this method.

One state, however, had not chosen its senators by single electorate block voting. Tasmania had used a form of proportional representationâthe Hare-Clark system. One of its senators pointed out in the Senate debate that under the proportional representation system it was almost impossible to say, in many cases, which candidates had received the highest number of votes without, in his words, `a thorough scrutiny of the ballot papers'. Because states had used different methods of election, senators were eager to stress that, whatever method was agreed to, it should not be regarded as a precedent binding future senates.

Following the 1914 double dissolution, senators were divided in the same way. In 1948, the method of electing senators was changed, with parliament adopting a system of proportional representation. Following the 1951 double dissolution, the Senate agreed, without dissent, to divide senators in the order in which they were elected.

In 1959, the Joint Committee of Constitutional Review recommended amending the constitution to provide for constitutional entrenchment of the method of allocating short- and long-term senators. The words were chosen carefully. The joint committee recommended allocating places to senators in `accord with their relative order of success.' The committee further noted that relative electoral success was different under first past the post and proportional representation.

Following the double dissolutions of 1974, 1975 and 1983, senators were divided in the traditional manner. In each case, there was no dissent in relation to the method chosen. In 1984, the Commonwealth Electoral Act was amended. Included was a new section 282. This section provided for the conduct of a recount with the quota that would have applied had a half Senate election been held after a double dissolution.

At the time of debate on this bill, Senator Ray, on behalf of the then government, stressed that, if this procedure were to be used to allocate short- and long-term senators, it should be agreed to in advance of any double dissolution election. Late in 1986, Senator Ray made approaches to the then opposition seeking their consideration of adopting the method made possible following a section 282 recount. The then opposition ignored the overture. Following the 1987 double dissolution, the Senate resolved to use the traditional method to allocate short- and long-term Senate places.

The coalition accused the ALP and the Australian Democrats of hypocrisy, stating that, having promoted a new system through the amendment to the Electoral Act, it ought to be used. Senator Ray, again on behalf of the then government, made it clear that, although the method provided for in section 282 was preferable for allocating places, the chamber had to agree in advance if the traditional method was not to be followed, because otherwise parties would adopt a wait and see approach and advocate the method that benefited them politically.

Given that it is almost impossible to predict the outcome of Senate elections under proportional representation, and that even small differences in voting patterns can have a significant impact on the final result, the opposition believes that it is appropriate for the Senate to resolve, as much as it is able, the appropriate method of allocating short- and long-term senators.

Since the inclusion of the provisions allowing a half Senate recount, it has been our view that this represents the fairest method of allocating short- and long-term Senate places. While proportional representation accurately distributes representation, it is a poor method of ranking senators according to voting strength. Any Senate candidate reaching a quota is ranked ahead of a senator elected by the distribution of a surplus from a candidate higher on the ticket.

Thus, the traditional arrangement favours minor parties. It ensures that they will receive a long-term senator as soon as they achieve quota. In a double dissolution election, this means that, provided they get over 7.69 per cent of the vote, they will receive a long-term senator, whereas a party which attracted 44 per cent of the vote may only receive two long-term senators. Such a result is inconsistent with the principle of proportional representation.

Order of election and voting strength are different concepts. Order of election simply reflects the order in which successful candidates reach quota. Voting strength more closely resembles proportional support for parties contesting the election.
Although the half Senate recount method is not perfect, it is a more accurate measure of voting strength. It is a more accurate measure of the will of the electorate than is the traditional method.

However, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Labor Party does not support determining the method of allocating places when the result is already known. I think such a practice encourages coalitions of self-interest to be built following each double dissolution election.

If a decision is to be made on this issue, it should be made now. Although it is doubtful that this Senate, by resolution, can bind a future Senate, a continuing order of the Senate stipulating the method of allocation would require an absolute majority of senators in any new parliament to overturn it. Further, it would have persuasive effect, both in this chamber and amongst the public at large, if there were a concerted attempt to alter the system after the election.

Because we acknowledge that matters affecting the election and terms of senators are sensitive ones, I have taken the opportunity of canvassing this issue in the Senate chamber today. The opposition has not had any discussions about this matter with other parties, but I do propose to present a notice of motion tomorrow to give effect to the proposal that I have put forward on behalf of the opposition here today.

Further, Mr Acting Deputy President, for the information of senators, I propose to table a research paper prepared at our request by the Parliamentary Library which extensively outlines the historical antecedents to this debate. In accordance with the normal courtesies, I, of course, provide it to the minister at the table. I formally seek leave to table this document.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to honour the passing of a hero. To do this, I would like to use the words of two people who knew Len Howard. One is Associate Professor Phil Jennings, Past President of the Conservation Council of Western Australia and current board member of the Conservation Council, and the other is Dr Nick Dunlop from the Brand Greens in Western Australia.

speech.para: These were the words of Phil Jennings at Len's funeral: Len Howard was a remarkable man. He was the sort of person who left a lasting impression on you even if you only met him once. He was a person filled with love of life and a passion for peace and justice and the environment. Len stood for these principles long before they became fashionable and at a time in life when most people want to retire and slow down Len embarked on one of the greatest challenges in his lifeâtrying to protect the State's largest inland waterway from inappropriate development.

For more than 20 years, in fact almost up to the day he died, Len campaigned tirelessly to protect the Peel Inlet, Harvey Estuary and Lake Clifton. He had to fight some of the most powerful and influential developers in our society. He lost many battles but he won the most important oneâthe respect and support of the people of Mandurah.

I first met Len in 1985 when he was already in his seventies. He was running a campaign to protect the Creery wetlands from a canal development. He invited me and a group of conservationists from Perth to visit the area to observe the samphire flats. His enthusiasm for the area was infectious and we all came away convinced that this was a very special site and one which must be conserved.

Over the succeeding years I worked with Len on many issues including the Dawesville Cut, the Peel Regional Park, Port Mandurah, Point Grey and the Creery Wetlands and Lake Clifton. These were all tough issues. Our opponents were wealthy, influential and determined, but Len was a tireless campaigner. He never gave up and he never let go.

I remember many phone calls from Len where he would begin by apologising for interrupting me and then go on to say he was just putting together a letter or a submission and needed some advice on how to word it or where to send it. I never minded helping him, I was full of admiration for the way he kept on going, relentlessly, when most other people had given the cause away.

Sometimes we would talk about politics and the future and I was amazed at how idealistic he was and how relevant his ideas were to the issues of today. Len was not just a leader of the conservation movement. He had a deep commitment to peace and he attended most of the Palm Sunday Peace rallies in Perth in the eighties and nineties. He was also committed to justice and social reform and he was a long term supporter of socialism which he believed was the basis of a just and sustainable society.

I will always remember Len as an outstanding grass roots campaigner. He motivated and inspired people with his commitment and vision. His passion for the environment affected those around him and they have taken up where he left off. That is perhaps his greatest contribution to society. The conservation movement in Mandurah today is strong and flourishing and it is full of wonderful, dedicated people who worked with Len on his many campaigns.

It wasn't always that way. When Len and Doreen settled in Mandurah in 1974 it was a developer's paradise. Very few people raised any concerns in those days about waterfront developments or the state of the estuary. However Len realised that unrestrained development would destroy the beautiful estuary which attracted people to Mandurah and in 1976 he and Brian Devereux decided to do something about it. They formed the Peel Preservation Group.

Len was always very modest about his work and he often told me how little he had managed to achieve. But the record of Len and the Peel Preservation Group is very impressive. The outstanding value of the Peel/Harvey/ Yalgorup System is now recognised by nearly everyone in the community and as a result the Government and the local Council have taken some steps to restore and protect it.

Just over three years ago I attended a retirement function in Mandurah at which the members of the Peel Preservation Group thanked Len and Doreen for the numerous contributions they had made to the conservation of the Peel area. For Len it was a difficult decision to step down from the leadership of the PPG after 18 years at the helm, but old age and ill health were beginning to catch up with him. He said to me at the time that he was happy to step down knowing that the group was in good hands, but he said that he wanted to go on campaigning to stop Port Mandurah Stage 2 and the Lake Clifton development.

And that he did. Over the last three years of his life, despite failing health, Len maintained a vigorous campaign to protect the stranded shoals and stromatolities in Lake Clifton. These tasks are unfinished, and the future of the Creery Wetlands still hangs in the balance, but I am sure that Len realised that his friends in the conservation movement would carry on the campaign he started more than 20 years ago.

Len was a gentle man. He never advocated violence or threats against his opponents. He always tried to convince them through reason and evidence. He worked tirelessly for social change. His telephone bills must have been enormous. He spoke to everyone he could and tried to arouse public awareness about the issues. He had a great faith in human nature and never lost hope that the truth would prevail. He was at his best working with ordinary people. Informing and encouraging them, believing that real change in society comes directly from the people. He wrote endless press releases, submissions and letters to the editors of newspapers with the aim of reaching the widest possible audience. And he undoubtedly succeeded in winning the support of the people of Mandurah for conserving the environment of the Peel Region.

In recognition of his work the Conservation Council awarded him the inaugural Bessie Rischbieth Award in 1994. This is the highest honour available to a conservationist and Len was the first person to receive it. Typically, in accepting the award, he said that he was deeply honoured by his selection but he was certain that there were others who deserved it more.

We have all lost a friend and a leader who was an inspiration to us. I am sure that we all feel the loss very deeply today because we realise that Len is irreplaceable. But as time goes by we will also rejoice that we knew him and that we shared in his success.
I have no doubt that his work will go on through the many people who worked with him and were inspired by him and I think that is what Len would have wanted most of all.
I would like to finish with the words of Dr Nick Dunlop who wrote the following on behalf of the Brand Greens:

On Thursday 16 April 1998 veteran wetlands campaigner, Green's member, candidate and friend, Len Howard, passed away. In the preceding fortnight he rang from Fremantle hospital about things that needed to be done to save samphire marshes and people he couldn't get in touch with. He didn't let on.

Len discovered the conservation significance of what we now know is the Peel-Yalgorup Ramsar wetland system long before its values were recognised. He campaigned for more than 20 years with the Peel Preservation Group to protect the estuary and lakes from the ever growing threat of urban encroachment, canal developments, pollution and general neglect.

Although in the last few years Len claimed that "the world was moving too fast" and "it was time to go to pasture", he never did. During the period he agreed to be drafted as a Green's candidate at the age of 80, won a landmark FOI case against the Federal Government and some environmental consultants, and relentlessly pursued the rescue of a productive marshland area from a canal development. The spectacle of a persistent, octogenarian, pensioner driving powerful developers, dubious consultants, self-serving councillors, journalists and government ministers to distraction was truly inspirational.

The Peel-Yalgorup region is the most important waterbird habitat area in Western Australia. It is April and the sandpipers from north-east Asia have fattened on Len's precious Creery mud-flats. They have taken flight in purposeful flocks to cross the world and find breeding grounds on the tundra. Perhaps Len's gone with them this time.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Labor Party: Selection of Candidates

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThis session of the Senate is for senators to speak about matters of public interest. Nothing could be more in the public interest than the way in which political parties go about their own business in selecting candidates to offer themselves to the Australian public at times of election.

speech.para: We knowâand it is very well known publiclyâof the enormous problems the ALP has in its preselection battles. What happened in Victoria with the branch stacking and vote rigging is legend.

talk.start.para: âYou're not serious!

âSenator Conroy interjects and, of course, he is one of the principal branch stackersâso the media say. I perhaps would not say that had it not been for such confirmation from the mediaâSenator Conroy, Senator Ray and Senator Carr; it is just legend. You cannot pick up a paper any day without understanding, without knowing, the branch stacking, the rorting, in the Victorian ALP branch.

speech.para: In New South Wales it is not much better. At this very moment we have the spectacle of the various authorities investigating allegations of criminals actually giving gifts to ALP members of state parliament to get them to perform certain favours in the parliament.

Who can forget that photograph of Peter Baldwin, when he was a Labor minister, coming out of a Labor meeting with blood streaming down his face where he had been set upon by other members of the ALP? They are the matters that we have come to accept as normal in the ALP in Victoria and New South Wales.

It is with some regret that I recount that this ALP malaise has come to Queensland. Regrettably, the current state leader of the ALP, Mr Beattie, either is part of it or is incapable and too weak to do anything about it. As a matter of public interest, I want to raise in this chamber today the disgraceful goings-on of the Australian Labor Party branches in the town that I come fromâthat is, Townsville in North Queensland.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember that the government of Queensland changed when a Liberal candidate was elected at the Mundingburra by-election. That Liberal candidate enabled the Queensland coalition to take government. That by-election came around because there was an improper election in the original contest in Mundingburra, so determined by the Court of Disputed Returns.

Following the Court of Disputed Returns overturning the Mundingburra result in the 1995 state election, the Liberal Party again re-endorsed Mr Frank Tanti. The man who ran for the Labor Party at that general election was a Mr Ken Davies, who was a minister in the Goss government. The Labor Party thought, for various factional reasons I think, that Mr Davies should be pushed aside in the by-election and they would get a glamour candidate to run in Mundingburra against Mr Frank Tanti.

The glamour candidate chosen by the Labor Party backroom boys was none other than Tony Mooney, the popular mayor of Townsville. Tony is not a bad fellow, and I think he does a reasonably good job. But he was put into this particular contest after a very difficult preselection battle. So Mayor Tony Mooney became the glamour candidate for the Labor Party, causing a lot of ill feeling, I might say, in relation to the preselection. The defeated preselection candidate, Mr Ken Davies, subsequently made allegations of bribery. He told the world and anyone who wanted to listen that the Labor Party had actually offered him trips to tropical islands and other inducements so that he would not run in the by-election.
Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Conroy.
âBut he chose to stand as an independent and, of course, he has suffered the penalty since then, and will suffer that for the rest of his life.
âHow about Parer? He's suffered.
âOrder! Senator Conroy, please.

âBut we had the glamour candidate against Frank Tantiâgood old battler Frank, a great friend of mine and a great representative for Mundingburra. Of course, Frank Tanti did the glamour candidate, the mayor of Townsville, like a dinner. But there was a lot of dissatisfaction in the branches of the ALP over that particular matter.

speech.para: So we then come to the other seats in Townsville. For those not familiar with the state scene up there, there is the seat of Mundingburra, now held by Mr Frank Tanti; there is the seat of Townsville, which was held by Mr Geoff Smith, a minister. Mr Smith announced that he was not going to stand again. I think he was given a bit of a shove and he moved on but Geoff is not a bad guy either. Then we have the preselection contest.
Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Conroy.
âWho was the preselection contest between in the state seat of Townsville? Let me tell you: there was the former mayor of Townsville, Mr Mike Reynolds from the Left.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNot one of your guys, Senator Conroy. Actually, they need you up there because the Right gets done like a dinner every time in Queensland. But you distract me. We had Mr Mike Reynolds, the former mayor of Townsville. He is an interesting guy and, again, quite a nice fellow. He resigned for some reason. What was he going to do? He had been a lecturer at the university. Guess what happened? He was able to get himself a job, supported by the then federal Labor government, down here in Canberra. He moved here for a couple of years. He left Townsville and became a Canberra citizen.

speech.para: Of course the Queensland state government at the time, the Goss Labor government, made sure he kept his sinecure as chairman of the Townsville Port Authority, which was rather interesting because he was living and working in Canberra but he was still chairman of the Townsville Port Authorityâand someone used to fly him up to Townsville every couple of weeks to attend to that. But that is an interesting sideline.

Anyway, Mike Reynolds thought he might like to be the state candidate for Townsville, so he nominated. But the Right wanted to put someone in so, again, we had Tony Mooney, the popular mayor. He also thought that was his seat by divine right. So we had the preselection contest between Mike Reynolds, former mayor from the Left, and Tony Mooney, current mayor from the Right.

As a result of that preselection, a lot of nasty comments went around. There were a lot of nasty rumours. There was a charge brought against Mayor Mooney's numbers man, Mr Andy Kehoe, for defrauding and rorting the electoral system.
Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Conroy.

âOn the day of the court case, after pleading his innocence all the way through, Mr Kehoe meekly went in and said, `I plead guilty.' Some unkind people suggested that he did that because if the court case had run ahead there would have been all these allegations involving Mike Reynolds, the candidate, and Mayor Tony Mooney and why it was that Mike Reynolds happened to end up winning the preselection for that seat of Townsville. So there was a charge and there was a conviction of an ALP numbers man for rigging the vote of the state electorate of Townsville.

speech.para: But now we go on to the third of the seats in the Townsville area; I have mentioned Mundingburra and Townsville. The third seat is the state seat of Thuringowa. There have always been a lot of rumours involving that contest for preselection. The original preselection candidates, as I recall, were a bloke named Gillman and a former Townsville City Council alderman, Ms Karen Ehrmann.
Right from the start, there were a lot of allegations about malpractice in the preselection. Karen Ehrmann from the Left won the preselection.
Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere we are, Senator Conroy, you have been done over by Senator Faulkner's lot yet again. Karen Ehrmann from the Left won the preselection. Then the allegations started flowing. The ALP had a number of internal investigations where ALP members spilled their all about what happened. A lot of these documents came from ALP members to Frank Tanti's office and to other Liberal Party people in Townsville, and they have been read out in the state parliament. They are all there on the record.

speech.para: I will just mention a couple of them. I am reading an article in the Courier-Mail that said:
Affidavits from several members of the ALP claimed that preselection ballot papers were taken, completed and lodged without the consent of residents.
It said further:
Ms Ehrmann had paid ALP membership fees in exchange for votes.
Senator Conroy, you would know about that sort of thing in the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âOh dear, oh dear!

âThe Courier-Mail also reported about a couple who had claimed that a blank ballot paper had been collected from their home and that their membership fees had been paid in exchange for electoral support.

speech.para: There were allegations in this article that `ALP sources say that they are an indication of massive vote tampering across the state.' Nevertheless, in spite of all these allegations and rumours, and investigations by the state branch of the ALP of people who do not live in particular areas having a vote in the preselection; in cases when they did not even know they had votedâsome of them did not even realise they were members of the ALP; I know this is not news to Senator Conroy who is obviously aware of these sorts of things, but this happened in my own city of TownsvilleâMs Ehrmann was endorsed as the Labor candidate for Townsville.

She was endorsed because the sitting member, Mr Ken McElligottâa nice fellow, Ken; in the past he has been a health minister and, as far as ALP politicians go, is quite a decent representative and a very decent manâgot a bit annoyed with all of this vote rigging going on and thought it was time to move on. He is quoted as saying, and it is the sort of thing that Ken would say, `It's time to step aside and give young parliamentarians a go.' He was saying, `I've had it; it's time I moved on. We want to let young people in. I've had my day; let's get some young people in.'

So Ken did that. And, as one would expect, like Keith De Lacy, the former Treasurer in Queensland who used to represent the seat of Cairns, for the last year they have done absolutely nothing. There is a decent coalition government in Queensland, but Keith De Lacy in the electorate of Cairns and Ken McElligott in the electorate of Thuringowa really have not done much. They have not been interested in their constituents; they are on a sort of pre-retirement leave. They did not appear in the press; there were no press releases. They didn't go to public functions as all politicians do, and, of course, the candidates were turning up insteadâMs Ehrmann.

But, lo and behold, a few months ago, Ken McElligott suddenly reappeared on the scene. Suddenly he started to issue press releases again; suddenly he started to attend functions. We all thought, `There's something funny going on here. Perhaps there is some truth in those rumours that Ms Ehrmann was involved in vote rigging. Perhaps there is some truth in the rumours that the ALP in Townsville has followed Graham Richardson's dictum of `whatever it takes' to get their factional mates into parliament.'

I have to say to you that, in spite of all of these rumours, Peter Beattie, the opposition leader, because he is simply too weak, went along with it. He would not do anything about these rumours, and they were rumours supported by affidavits from ALP members. Peter Beattieâabsolutely useless, absolutely weakârefused to do anything about it.

What he did do is that he said, as recently as a couple of days ago, that he was going to go along and launch Ms Ehrmann's campaign for the state electorate of Thuringowa and that he was going to do it this coming Saturday. He has said that he has confidence in Ms Ehrmann. Ms Ehrmann in fact said:
I welcome the launch of my campaign by Peter Beattie. It is another slap in the face for the member for Mundingburra, Frank Tantiâ
I am not sure how she got to thatâ
who has attempted to undermine me with lies and innuendos.

And so it went on. So we have this guy who was too old to stay there retiring, Karen Ehrmann saying that she was going to be the candidate and Beattie saying she was going to be the candidate. And what happened yesterday?

Last night, Karen Ehrmann received summonses for breaches related to vote rigging. And guess who is the bloke who popped up very early this morning to say that he would be the candidate? The previous member, who only a few short months ago had said it was time to step aside and give a young guy a go. Of course, the young guy who is having a go and who will win that seat is David Moore, the Liberal candidate. But again, the ALPâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Australian public has seen considerable evidence of the closeness of the relationship between the Howard government, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) and his staff, and the Patrick Stevedores company. It was described by Senator Faulkner yesterday as a symbiotic relationship, and so it is. Both Mr Reith and Patrick are wrapped up together, their futures inextricably linked. But how much do we know about Patrick Stevedores, the shadowy group so hell-bent on sacking their entire work force that they will do and say anything?

speech.para: It does not take much digging to come up with the real and nasty details about this group of corporate felons, because the legitimate business community of this country is so disgusted by the industrial and corporate tactics of this bunch that they have been freely talking to the Labor Party. So let us consider the history of the people from Patrick and the related companies, Lang Corp, Jamison Equities and Brencorp.

I have spoken in this place a number of times regarding my understanding that the National Crime Authority are currently investigating the sale of $US105 million worth of Elders convertible bonds to BHP which generated a profit to the bond holders of $A78 million. I believe that there are strong grounds to say that Chris Corrigan and Peter Scanlon were the architects and executors of this sham transaction to defraud the shareholders and creditors of Elders and regulatory authorities.

I believe there is a strong case that Peter Scanlon and Chris Corrigan conspired to defraud the shareholders of Elders of $78 million; secretly used Bankers Trust funds to fund the purchase of the convertible bonds; knew at all times the beneficial owners of the convertible bonds; failed to disclose the names of the beneficial owners to either Bankers Trust or the Elders shareholders; devised the scheme to defraud the shareholders of Elders; and in conjunction with Richard Wiesener executed the proposal. They are currently the subject of investigation by the National Crime Authority. Knowing this to be the case, John Howard and Peter Reith chose Peter Scanlon and Chris Corrigan as their partners to sack 1,400 waterside workers.

When the NCA investigations of two payments from Elders to Mr Alan Hawkins, totalling $66.5 million, came to light, both John Elliott and Peter Scanlon denied that the transactions were shams and gave long, detailed accounts to the NCA under oath as to why the transactions had been made. Ken Jarrett and Peter Scanlon told the NCA that the transactions had been done with their knowledge on John Elliott's instructions and for a genuine reason.

The evidence shows that the transactions were a sham and that by the end of the case the sham nature of the transactions was not even disputed by the accused. Peter Scanlon admitted on the day of his acquittal that the transactions were shams but claimed they had been used to discharge a debt genuinely and legitimately owed to Hawkins; one that he has never been able to produce paperwork forâsays it got lostâbut is a genuine transaction that they owed the debt on. Scanlon also claimed that the choice of a sham vehicle for discharging the debt had been the choice of Ken Jarrett alone.

As the prosecution case statement makes clear, Peter Scanlon lied to the NCA in giving evidence about the payments to Hawkins; Peter Scanlon lied to further the conspiracy to defraud the shareholders of Elders; Peter Scanlon and John Elliott lied because they knew that if the NCA became aware of the true reasons of the payments to Hawkins that might attract attention to the true beneficial owners of this $US105 million parcel of convertible bonds. In June 1984, Elders made an issue of $US160 million of convertible bonds to raise capital and to enable executives to take up a financial interest that would be self-funded.
In his statement to the court, Ken Jarrett, the then business associate intricately involved in this, said:
The scheme to finance executive participation was proposed initially by Bankers Trust.
The scheme to finance executive participation was proposed by Bankers Trust, whose chief executive at the time was Chris Corrigan.

Of the $US160 million, $US105 million was taken up by the executives of Elders. Close Scanlon associate Richard Wiesener organised the placement to conceal executive participation. Funding was provided by the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, Bankers Trust and Credit Agricole. The interest payments on the borrowed funds used to purchase the convertible bonds was met by Elders, not by the beneficial owners who incurred no risk. BHP purchased the $US105 million parcel of Elders convertible bonds on 10 and 11 April 1985, which produced a profit to the beneficial owners of $78 million.
In his statement to the court Ken Jarrett again saidâand I quote:

I was later told by Elliott that my share had been reduced in favour of Scanlon because Scanlon felt he deserved more than his original allocation for the pivotal role he had played in generating the profit.

According to Peter Stussi, an accounts manager with Bank Cantrade in Switzerland, he recalls significant deposits coming in to a number of bank accounts at the time when the convertible bonds were sold in 1986. Ken Jarrett told the NCA that after the profits were placed in the bank accounts the nominees names that operated the bank account with fictitious directors was changed and Peter Stussi has confirmed these events. Peter Scanlon and John Elliott went to Switzerland on a number of occasions to discuss the operation of these accounts. This is despite the fact that both Elliott and Scanlon maintain they do not know the beneficial owners of those bank accounts.

talk.start.para: âWhy would you believe him?

âBelieve Elliott? You would have to be pretty much a mug. The names of the beneficial owners of the profits from the sale of the convertible bonds is currently a matter of investigation for the NCA. The role of Bankers Trust was critical. The concept for the convertible bonds issue and the interest rate conditions attached to the bond issue were developed by Rowan Ross and David Ryan of Bankers Trust who reported direct to chief executive Chris Corrigan. Richard Wiesener acted for the three shelf companies incorporated in the Bahamas: AMST, Bartex Securities and West Fin Company who, he said, did not want to use their own money to pay for the Eurobonds and that his clients did not want to be identified. Funding of the convertible bonds was organised by BT who provided some of the funds along with Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank and Credit Agricole. BT organised the interest rate exposure with Wiesener. John Elliott and Peter Scanlon shifting the interest rate credit risk to Elders rather than to the bond holders.

speech.para: There appears to have been no disclosure of this risk to Elders shareholders and in this case the non-disclosure would be grossly improper. This manoeuvre enabled BT to argue that it did not have to check who the beneficial owner of the companies located in the Bahamas were because Elders was underwriting the credit risk albeit without their own shareholders' knowledge. BT's lawyers requested a letter of confirmation that was produced by Richard Wiesener. The National Crime Authority have a copy of this letter. When Chris Corrigan got the letter from Richard Wiesener saying that Wiesener's clients were not Elders directors, Chris Corrigan used this letter as an excuse to avoid carrying out a probity check that would have disclosed the real identity of those to whom BT was lending the money.

BT received large commissions as a consequence of this illegal and improper transaction. The purchase of the Elders convertible bonds and their ultimate sale at a profit of $78 million would not have been possible without Chris Corrigan. During this period Chris Corrigan gained Scanlon's confidence, and it is not surprising that he subsequently appointed Scanlon as head of Langcorp.

Let us turn from Corrigan's and Scanlon's involvement with John Elliott and Harlin/Elders to involvement with another of the `big six' of the 1980s corporate scam cases. Records from the ASC show that Peter Scanlon was a director of the Linter Group during the 1980s. Linter Group is well known as the corporate scam vehicle of one Abraham Goldberg now in exile in Poland and still being sought by corporate regulators in this country over losses at least as great as those incurred by Christopher Skase. Greater than $750 million.

Allegedly during the 1980s Abe Goldberg took over a number of valuable Australian textile brands such as Speedo, Bradmill, King Gee and Exacto. He stripped those assets of all value and left them as shells of debt. Goldberg is alleged to have exported many millions of dollars through a number of complex company deals, including through companies in Monacoâwhich rings a bell againâand is now living high on the hog on those stolen shareholder funds. And what role did Peter Scanlon play in this? He was a member of the central company board and if he was fulfilling his duties as a director he should have known exactly what Goldberg was up to. What is more, anyone who has ever seen Peter Scanlon operate in Harlin, Elders, AFP Investments or Langcorp know that Scanlon is not a passive director. He is very active directing and controlling corporate strategy, take-overs, financing, shareholdings and money trails. In fact, it is well known that Abe Goldberg was impressed by Scanlon's corporate strategies. Colleen Ryan and Karen Maley wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald on the 30 April 1994 that:

Former close associates talk about how Goldberg was enthralled by the glamour and the financial wizardry of the AFP crew that included Wiesener, Scanlon, John Gerahty. Goldberg did not stick to his knitting. He was entranced by the entrepreneurs.

And the entrepreneurs were also entranced with Abe Goldberg and his tactics. Scanlon has used Goldberg-like asset stripping techniques on the Patrick Stevedores labour hire companies, the only difference being the desired end result, an easy sacking of the work force.

Similarly, another close Goldberg associate had a $55 million debt repaid by Goldberg immediately before the Linter Group empire went under. There are clear similarities with the behaviour of Patrick's bankers 15 minutes before liquidation of the labour hire companies late at night.

But Peter Scanlon did not leave his Linter experience behind when he left the board. He took with him at least seven former directors and officers of Linter Group into his own companies. ASC records indicate that the following names show up on both Linter Group records and those of Scanlon com panies such as AFP Investment Corp Ltd, Jamison Equity Ltd, Brencorp Pty Ltd and Patrick Stevedores companies, including the labour hire companies: David Fitzsimons, Basil Sellers, Ronald Melgaard, William Gerahty, Robin Crawford, David Vaux and Evan Williams.

Clearly those former close associates of Abe Goldberg had important and valuable skills for Peter Scanlon's future corporate shenanigans. Peter Scanlon and Chris Corrigan stand condemned for their past corporate malpractices, for their personal history and their associates left over from their Elders and Linter involvement. These two have considerable form and the legitimate business community have been deafening in their lack of support for Langcorp's corporate manoeuvrings.
It is now clear that Peter Reith is a conniving co-conspirator with corporate crooks.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I ask you to withdraw that. It is a reflection on the minister in the other chamber.
âI withdraw.
âThank you.
âPeter Reith head hunted the corporate world for the worst remaining corporate crooks from the 1980s who he knew would not hesitate to break the law in order to achieve his endsâ
âOrder! That is a reflection on Minister Reith. I ask you to withdraw it. It imputes a motive to him. I ask you to withdraw it. Withdraw it, Senator Conroy.
âI withdraw.
âThank you.

âThe Howard government stands condemned for having hitched their wagon so closely to corporate fiends such as Scanlan and Corrigan. Does the government now say they knew of the history of Corrigan and Scanlan and willingly formed a partnership with these men on the waterfront? Or did they dupe you, pulled the wool over your eyes so easily? Whatever the case, we could easily say the Howard government deserves everything they get, which so far has been abject failure and derision. Unfortunately, Australia did not deserve the debacle this government has produced on the nation's waterfronts through its disastrous partnership with Chris Corrigan and Peter Scanlan.

âChair, that was an extraordinary speech. Accusations have been cobbled together and it is the worse conspiracy theory I have ever heard. I would like to pull the speech to pieces bit by bit, but perhaps at another time.

speech.para: I rise to refer to speeches and warnings issued by Mr Graeme Samuel, President of the National Competition Council, as reported in the press in recent months. I ask: by what authority is Mr Samuel able to threaten the public, industries, the professions and, in fact, every inhabitant of the states, that schools, hospitals and police funding will be unavailable from state coffers because of the lack of competition reforms?

Mr Samuel, I point out to you that the NCC is not a policy maker. You are beyond the reach of the electorate but the electorate expects us, the politicians, to point out to you where you are wrong in no uncertain terms. Is it not deliberate scare mongering to assume the loss of hospitals, schools and police? Surely these utterances exceed any of the functions or responsibilities given to him or his council under any legislation.

To quote from the NCC annual report, the responsibility of the NCC is to assess whether jurisdictionsâthe states and territoriesâhave made satisfactory progress in implementing their reform commitments and to make recommendations to the Commonwealth Treasurer about national competition policy payments to the states and territories.

Mr Samuel in his public utterances has overstepped the mark and is pre-empting and prejudicing reviews which state governments are undertaking. Under the 1995 NCP agreement, the state and territory governments in relation to the legislation review agreed to review and, where appropriate, to reform all laws which restrict competition and ensure that any new restrictions provide a net community benefit. The three tranches are assessed on 1 July 1997, 1999 and 2001, with payments to state and territory governments of around $16 billion over the period 2005 to 2006.

Coming out as he has this year, the tone of his comments can only be construed as threats to the states ahead of the delivery of their reviews, as bully boy tactics to the states, to the affected industries and to the professions concerned. He has left no-one out: liquor regulations, newsagents, chemistsâthe backbone of many small communities. Your call for deregulation destroys them. You transfer their business to large supermarkets in neighbouring towns and destroy the smaller town with its pub, newsagent and chemist serving the local community.

What sort of communities are we going to end up with? There will be no enterprise, no opportunity for small business people. There is a loss of competition from small business. He makes no mention of the valid consideration that national competition policy gives to social factors as part of the public benefit consideration.

Mr Samuel last week gave a speech in Adelaide to shake up the professional groups and local governments. He has also attacked statutory marketing reforms. His complaints are extraordinary. He maintains that there should not be any industry representatives on review panels, that the council is opposed to the appointment of industry representatives. He says that `there is a risk of the review panel being captured by vested interest.' How else is the relevant total picture of an industry to be given if it is not by someone involved in it? Maybe when it comes to the implementation of competition policy, an interested party could also be defined as economists who have a direct interest in the implementation of their current pure ideology.

Mr Samuel is particularly critical of the review into the sugar, rice and barley industries. In February he made accusations of political expediency affecting decisions. The sugar industry working party review was a total industry review. It had 74 recommendations, one being the retention of the single desk marketing of the Queensland Sugar Corporation. It was a decision agreed by the growers, the millers, the refiners and also the end-users who are the customers of the single desk seller. This one desk selling, which allows the forward selling of sugar, has driven this industry to be hugely successful. It is a $2 billion export industry today. Where is the increased productivity when one mill is set against the other, driving the price down to international buyers?

In the circumstances, accusations of political expediency are outrageous. Surely the purpose of reforms is not to destroy industries and destroy communities which depend on these industries. What about consideration of the job losses and the lack of replacement jobs in country Australia? What about industry being the sole economic base of many rural areas. Where are these factors taken into consideration in Mr Samuel's pre-determined judgments? What about consideration of the reality of the markets that primary industries have to sell into?

The state government reviews of the dairy industries are due this year in New South Wales and Queensland. State governments are legitimately allowed to take into consideration the public benefit test. State governments are elected by the people and are in a far better position to know the public benefits of an industry arrangement than a council sitting in Melbourne. Is it the responsibility of elected state governments to govern and consider the needs of other constituents and the wellbeing of the state as part of their elected role as representatives and deliverers of good government to their people?

Mr Samuel is forgetting the public benefit test when he makes his threat of withholding the loot. Where are the assessments that have followed the deregulation of certain industries such as the egg industry where the consumer has not received lower prices, the producer has received lower prices with the price benefit picked up by the retailer because they have huge market power?

The same will happen with the dairy industry with the producer screwed down by the large processors and the supermarket chains. Only the big can survive as big chains tender to big processors who are the only ones who can meet these contracts. What about the closure of smaller processing plants, whether dairy or sugar, which are the mainstay of rural economies?

Recent years have seen the growth of the bigâand you have to be big to compete in a marketplace dominated by the big. Where are the assessments that follow from deregulation of primary industries when in Australia the reality is they must sell to a domestic market controlled by three large retailers? The three large supermarket chains control nearly 80 per cent of the domestic retail grocery market. These retailers are provided with their own protection. Their monopoly power is beyond any intervention of the Hilmer competition reforms. Hilmer competition rules maintain competition still exists with three large grocery buyers. In reality there is no competition for the sellers.

The Hilmer reforms give the three large retailers their own market arrangements and they receive their own form of protection. Every beef producer, pork producer, egg producer, vegetable and fruit grower has the same story of being captive to the three large retail buyers where they are 80 per cent of grocery retail market.

Domestic prices are set by them. Control over product specifications are set by them with expensive penalties the discretion of their buyers if product specifications are not met. All power rests with the buyer. The absolute right to have a buyer for your product depends on playing exactly to the rules of the big chainsârules that can be changed at any time by the buyer. Ask any pork producer or a beef producer struggling to survive in the totally deregulated selling environment. The sellers are economic captives of the near monopoly powers of the three large retailers. Beef producers have been selling below the cost of production for the past three years. Supermarkets control 40 per cent of all retail beef sales in Australia. The supermarkets set the price for the wholesale market and the supermarkets take advantage of the strength of their enterprise and deal with the producers.

The consequences are that the production side continues to collapse, not being able to survive at these prices. Production and quality decline as breeders' stock is disposed of and producers struggle to maintain some sort of viability. Services are closed, their investment value is lost and vital export earnings are lost to the nation.

Is this the whole picture that Mr Samuel should allow the states to considerâvital factors such as the survival of industries in rural areas and their processing plants when considering the public benefit of arrangements like the Queensland Sugar Corporation or the Rice Marketing Board?

Mr Samuel's comments are unveiled threats. I say to Mr Samuel: let the state governments and their elected representatives play the game and you can keep the score. If you want to be a politician stand for the position or stay out of politics. Mr Samuel, let the process work as it should with the state governments. Your threats should not prevent state governments from doing their job and looking at social and regional issues and considering the public benefit factor in any competition reform decisions.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the statement made by Mr Costello in June 1995 when he said:

question.para: . . . the first thing we'll do is we'll have to deal with the current account deficit.

Is this how the government deals with the current account deficitâby creating a record deficit of $31 billion and a record foreign debt of $222 billion? When will the government deal with the current account deficit rather than increase it? Does the minister stand by Mr Costello's further statement that:
. . . you can't have high growth in this country when you've got a current account deficit that runs over this country month after month with $2b deficits.
Does the government stand by the Treasurer's statement when it is running deficits on an average of $2.5 billion month after month?

talk.start.para: âSenator Cook, that is astonishing after what has virtually been universally acclaimed as a superb budget. Some of the journalists have referred to it as a great budgetâa budget in tune with the times. I have to say, Senator Cook, there is no greater endorsement for the quality of this budget than that which comes from looking at the doleful faces on the Labor Party and the appalling leadership that you have received over the last two years. We are well aware that there is a crisis in Asia, and we are well aware that the effect of that crisis is to impact on the balance of payments. Equally, Senator Cook, it has been pointed out by othersâ
âSenator, your remarks should be addressed to the chair, not directly to the questioner.

âMadam President, I was pointing out to Senator Cook that the budget papers very clearly explain the nature of the current account deficit, and the fact that this is a different type of current account deficit to the blow-outs that were experienced under the Labor Party. Those blow-outs, as you will be aware, were driven by very high domestic demand, high inflation and asset price explosion. It is very clear, and we have acknowledged this in the budget papers, that where there is a major downturn in Asiaâwhere many of our major export markets areâthis clearly will have an impact on exports, and it will clearly have an impact on the current account deficit.

answer.para: The answer to Senator Cook is best given today by the enormous plaudits that the Treasurer has received for this budget: a budget which is responsible; a budget which is in tune with the times; and a budget which reflects the tough measuresâwhich we have acknowledgedâwhich we have had to take to repair the massive fiscal deficit which was left to this country by Labor. I suggest that the Labor Party, rather than trying to make mean and spiteful comments about a great budget, would be better off to draw the lessonâ

talk.start.para: âWe asked you a question about debt and you won't answer.

âYou ask me about debt. Foreign debt, as we know, exploded under the Labor Party. There is no question that under the Labor Party, with the massive deficits under the treasurership of Mr Keating, there was an explosion of foreign debt and no-one has argued that. That is one of the problems that this government has had to cope with, and one of the problems that we are coping with particularly well. I suggest to the Labor party: go back and read the press this morning; go back and read the transcripts of the TV commentators; look at the enormous range of very positive comments that this government is receiving for its very responsible behaviour. You would be better served, rather than with the sort of nitpicking that Senator Cook is indulging in.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note your answer, Minister, but I also note that Mr Howard, Mr Costello and Mr Fischer have been saying in recent months that the Australian economy is fireproofed from the Asian contagion. It is interesting that you should raise that excuse now. Minister, can you explain why your prediction for the current account deficit is 5.25 per cent of GDP as compared with the prediction of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Macfarlane, who has it at six per cent? Is the difference between your prediction and that of Mr Macfarlane due to methodology; is it due to different judgments or is it just a case of political expediency?

âSenator Cook, I think if you read the budget papers carefully you will see that the 5.25 per cent is a year figureâan average figure. Mr Macfarlane may have been referring to a different time period. It could well be a timing factor, but I think the projections by the Reserve Bank and the projections by the Treasury are broadly consistent. I urge people in the Labor Party, if they have any doubts about this budget, to read very carefully the press comments this morning. You will see, once again, that the Labor Party is completely out of kilter with national sentiment.

âMy question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The coalition government was elected on a platform to be economically responsible, to reduce debt, to increase savings and to assist families and small business. Will the government leader inform the Senate how last night's budget builds upon outstanding progress already made by the Howard government and how the budget has restored confidence to the Australian economy which was so badly undermined by 13 years of Labor government?

âCertainly. This budget again demonstrates that this is a government of economic and fiscal credibility, which is in stark contrast to the former Labor government which is now in opposition. It demonstrates again that the government in office, the Howard government, is the only alternative in Australian politics which has a policy of economic responsibility.

answer.para: That has been recognised overwhelmingly, as Senator Kemp said, Madam President, but I will just remind you of two organisations and their expressions last night. The Business Council of Australia said:
This is a Budget that is absolutely right for the times. Most importantly, the Howard Government has honoured its promise to the Australian people by delivering a Budget surplus.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:

This is a good Budget which leaves the Australian economy stronger and more resilient. This is a Budget which will help the Australian economy onto a more productive path to the future. The Government, having set out on this path two years ago, has stayed on course. The benefits are now there for all to see.

What are these benefits? Labor's $10.3 billion black hole has now been turned into a $2.7 billion surplus. We now have record low interest rates of about 6.5 per cent, saving the average Australian home buyer $320 a month, or $3,800 per year.

Small business overdraft interest rates are now down to 7.7 per cent, perhaps the lowest ever. Compare that with Labor's achievement of over 20 per centâover 20 per cent with Labor and down to 7.7 per cent with the coalition. Unemployment has fallen to its lowest level in eight yearsâthat is, since the Labor recession that Mr Keating said we had to have. And that has all been achieved without tax increasesâno increases in income tax, no increases in company tax, and no new increases in wholesale sales tax.

Compare the leadership. Look at the record of the alternative Prime Minister. When Mr Beazley was minister for employment, one million Australians were out of work and there was an 11.2 per cent unemployment rate. When he was minister for finance, there was a $10.3 billion budget deficitârecord high budget deficits. Government debt grew to nearly $80 billion over five years. What a record to stand by and to put yourself up on as an alternative Prime Minister in this country. There is the contrast. If Labor were back in government, what would you have? You would have billions of dollars of debt again.
Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe would be dangerously exposed to things such as the Asian crisis, Senator Cook. There would be higher interest rates, higher unemployment and higher taxes because that is the way that Labor does business. That is its record. What is so disappointing is that, although Mr Gareth Evans has owned up and said, `Yes, we did leave this huge debt,' Senator Cook continues to deny it.

answer.para: Before the election, Senator Cook denied that there was a deficit. He assured the Australian people that the budget would be in surplus. Since the election, he has denied that there was a deficit. It is time for Senator Cook to rise to his feet and say, `I misled the people before the election and I have misled the people since the election.' Only then will Senator Cook start to have the credibility to justify his asking his first question.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Leader of the Government in the Senate inform the Senate of community reaction to last night's budget?
âMadam President, that would take the whole hour of question time, but I will give you just a few more examples. The Institute of Chartered Accounts said:

answer.para: The Treasurer's Budget, which delivers an underlying surplus of $2.7 billion during the next financial year, is a responsible and encouraging reaction to the present economic situation.
On tourism, the Tourism Council of Australia commented:
A record increase in funding for tourism in tonight's Budget is good news for the industry.
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe Minerals Council said:

answer.para: The Federal Government should be congratulated. The fiscal management performance is good news.
The housing industry said:
The Federal Government's commitment to a substantial budget surplus has to be welcomed as the right defence for Australia against the Asian problems.
Please note that, Senator Cook. On aged care, what did the Council on the Ageing say, Senator Cook? It said:
Health care is one of the most important public policy issues for older people. The government's focus on this area in the budget is welcome.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. In the first Howard budget, the Treasurer forecast employment growth of 1Â½ per cent; the outcome was 1Â¼ per cent. Last year, the forecast for employment growth was two per cent; the outcome was again 1Â¼ per cent. So, in the last two budgets, the government got it wrong to the tune of tens of thousands of jobs. Can the minister explain how the government can predict higher employment growth from 1998 to 1999 when economic growth for the corresponding period is predicted to fall by three-quarters of a per cent?

âI think we should put a few figures on the record here, Senator Mackay, which might give a slightly different spin to the effort you just made. The context of your question comes after recent figures on employment growth in the Australian economy of over 50,000. That is a really remarkable figure and one that, again, was widely welcomed in the community. Senator Mackay, you seemed to be saying that there was a fall in growth this year. Is that what you said?
âNo, I didn't say that!
âYou saidâ
âSenator Kemp!

âMadam President, I am trying to get some clarification from Senator Mackay because I did think she said that there was a fall in growth this year. Growth is rising this year, Senator Mackay. Haven't you read the budget figures?
âOrder! Address the chair, please. Don't shout across the chamber.
âI am intrigued by a question asked by a Labor Party senator that indicates to this chamber that growth is going to fall this year. I just think it is absolutely astonishing.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is right, growth is predicted at three per cent. Senator Mackay said that growth was falling.
âNo, I did not!
âAll I am saying to Senator Mackay is: be very careful when you take questions from the questions committee.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere are far too many interjections. Senator Mackay, you will have an opportunity to ask a supplementary question if you wish.

âAs Senator Mackay will be aware, the figures in the budget papers show that the unemployment rate at the end of next year is predicted to come down to 7Â¾ per cent, which is a further fall on the current figures. These are the lowest figures in the unemployment area for a long time.

answer.para: Contrary to what you are saying, Senator Mackay, this government has a very proud record in this area, and a record which we are continuing to work hard on. If I can refresh your memory, unemployment under Labor rose toâwas it 11.2 per cent? Does anyone here know who the minister for employment was under Labor when the unemployment level rose to 11.2 per cent? Absolutely dead silence. I can tell you, Madam President, the minister for employment was Mr Kim Beazley. Mr Beazley presided over an unemployment figure of 11.2 per cent. What an absolutely splendid record!

We now have a Labor Party senator standing up here and purporting to criticise this government's record. Senator Mackay, don't you realise that the unemployment rate has come down under this government? Don't you realise that the unemployment rate is predicted to further decline?

talk.start.para: âSenator, address the chair, please.

âI was just asking some rhetorical questions, because there was an implication in the question from Senator Mackay that this government was somehow failing on this front. The truth of the matter is that this government is making great progress on this front. This is what the budget figures say. Just to repeat an earlier comment: the economy is not going to suffer a fall in growth this year; the economy is growing at three per cent.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Treasurer last night predicted a fall in growth of three quarters of a per cent. That is what I said. Just so you understand that. My supplementary question is: has the minister ordered, given that the forecasts have been so appallinglyâ
âMadam President, I raise a point of order: the honourable senator opposite is not addressing her remarks through the chair. I would hope that she would be asked to do so.
âSenator Mackay, phrase your question correctly, please, to comply with the standing orders.

âMy supplementary question is: given that the government's reviews with regard to unemployment have been so wrong in the last two budgets and given that the Treasurer last night actually predicted a fall in growth of three quarters of a per cent, Minister, have you ordered a review of the employment growth forecasts given the flawed predictions of the last two budgets?

âI think what we should do is order a review of the questions committee in the Labor Party for putting up such an absurd question. I repeat: growth next year is forecast at three per cent. I am very pleased to report that the government has delivered on its promise to have a return to surplus in the first parliamentary term, further projected surpluses over the period 2001-02 and is on track to more than halve the debt ratio, the Commonwealth general government net debt, by the turn of the century.

By moving the budget into surplus we are now repaying the debt burden inherited from the previous government. By the end of 1998-99 we will have repaid around $31 billion in net debt from the levelsâ

âSenator Kempâ

âMadam President, I raise a point of orderâ

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. âThank you, Madam President, for that ruling. It is true that it was a very broad ranging question. What we have been able to do as a result of this is to see very strong benefits flowing towards the wider Australian community.

You only have to look at the figures I quoted in reference to an excellent question I received from Senator Ross Lightfoot in relation to the effect of the cuts in interest rates on home mortgage rates and the savings that the average family receives. talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. With respect, as the minister did not answer my question, I will try again. Minister, there is no doubt there was a deficit. I am simply asking you: is it not the case that it was $3 billion smaller than you forecast and than you prepared your responses for?
âMadam President, I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Democrats is asking a question direct to the minister rather than through you.
âI have no intention of pulling everyone up every time, but I shall persist in trying to get standing order 186 adhered to in the chamber. I hope that people will gradually learn to do so.

âThank you, Madam President. I will try again through you. Is it not the case, as the minister's answer implied, that of course we had a deficit but that it was $3 billion less than forecastâin other words, we have had $3 billion worth of cuts and harsh measures that were unnecessary and that those people in Australia who are least able to withstand those cuts have effectively suffered for nothing?

âAgain, I have to say that it is an astonishingly misconceived question. Senator, as a result of all the things that we have done, we have been able to deliver a substantial budget surplus at last. I know the Labor Party do not like it, and we have seen the nitpicking which has gone on today. The Democrats are a bit upset about something which I cannot quite work out. âThat's not true!

âI just think this is astonishing. All these figures are detailed, Senator. If you want to look at the growth in spending in particular areas and new measures, they are all there in the budget papers, in the midyear review. I do not know what you are going on about.

âI don't remember that.
