Of course, when those figures started to mount up, all those promises had to be immediately dumped, with egg all over the collective face of the Australian Labor Party. (Time expired)

âI draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of former New South Wales Senator, Michael Baume. I wish you a happy and pleasant return to this country and to the Senate.
âHear, hear!

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. On 12 August 1997, Dr Peter Bridgewater, the government's Supervising Scientist, wrote to the Alligator Rivers Advisory Committee in relation to the Jabiluka Uranium Mine and said, in part:

question.para: If ERA were to proceed with the Jabiluka mill alternative, I would recommend, in the strongest possible terms to the Minister for the Environment, that ERA be required to prepare a new Environmental Impact Statement as required by the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Statements by ERA have indicated that it believes that a new EIS would be required in order to proceed with the Jabiluka mill alternative.

Given this statement by the government's senior uranium mining scientist, the person responsible for the protection of Kakadu National Park from uranium mining, why has the government dismissed this advice and instead allowed ERA to proceed with a much less stringent public environmental review of the on-site mill alternative for the proposed Jabiluka Uranium Mine?

talk.start.para: âIn response to Senator Margetts, the Jabiluka mill alternative was proposed in the EIS as a feasible mine development strategy should a situation develop where milling at Ranger was no longer an option, in accordance with Minister Hill's recommendations. Senator Margetts will be aware that, of all the options available, both from an environmental and economic point of view, certainly the milling at Ranger would be the most desirable.

answer.para: In accordance with Minister Hill's recommendations, I required ERA to provide further information to the Commonwealth if ERA wished to develop this Jabiluka mill alternative. On 22 April 1998, Energy Resources of Australia was designated as the proponent under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 in relation to the Jabiluka mill option of the Jabiluka development proposal.

Senator Hill has now determined that a public environment reportâa PERâwill be required for the Jabiluka mill. The PER will enable further public and government scrutiny of the additional information provided by ERA which relates to specific impacts of milling Jabiluka ore on-site. It is consistent with Senator Hill's recommendation that further environmental assessment should be required if the preferred option of milling at Ranger did not proceed.

It must be remembered that the EIS addressed the mining operations and the proposed haul road as well as the Ranger milling option, and these aspects of the proposal have already been given environmental clearance by Senator Hill. ERA have not notified the Commonwealth of which milling option will be progressed. It is likely that they will make this decision in light of ongoing and continuing discussions with Aboriginal interests associated with the Jabiluka project. I consider there would be no impediment to ERA progressing development of mining operations common to both options subject to requirements I placed on the company, the issue of the appropriate Northern Territory authorisations and their commercial judgment. We all recognise the importance of the biophysical, cultural and social significance of the location of the mine, and I have advised ERA that I expect the company to demonstrate that stringent environment, heritage and safeguard requirements have been met before I consider issuing an export permit.

I will just respond briefly to the comment about Dr Bridgewater. I think the comment made by Senator Margetts is probably correct, but I might also say that, when Senator Hill decided there would be a public environment report, this in itself was supported by Dr Bridgewater.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that ERA has said that it plans to begin construction at any time, has it now become government policy to allow highly sensitive mining projects to proceed before legally required environmental review processes are completed? Senator Parer has indicated that there has been ongo ing and continuing discussions with Aboriginal interests. Is the minister aware that the traditional owners of that area are asking in all possible terms that an EIS take place before a proposal were considered for milling at Jabiluka?

âI thought when I answered that question in a lot of detail that in fact I did give Senator Margetts the response she wantedâthat where the environmental work has been going out, subject to Northern Territory agreements and so on, there is nothing to prevent them from going ahead in accordance with those approvals already received. What we are looking at now is an alternative process for the milling of uranium at Jabiluka, rather than the Ranger option. That will require a public environment report and, until that happens, they cannot go with the Jabiluka milling option.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Last night's budget included significant boosts to health care in a number of areas. Will the minister outline the specific initiatives for public hospitals, preventative health, indigenous health and any other measures which assist Australians and their families?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure to respond to Senator Payne's question and inform the Senate about the positive initiatives this government is undertaking in building a stronger health system. Madam President, as you know, last night a budget was delivered which some commentators have said has put this country in a better position than it has been in for at least 25 years in relation to the economy. As part of that budget last night, we have introduced extra funding in relation to health care.

answer.para: The Howard government will make available an extra $2.9 billion for public hospitals over the next five years. That is a 15 per cent increase in real terms in Commonwealth spending, to a total of $30.2 billion. The budget measures represent a genuine balance between maintaining the government's commitment to achieving reform across health and family services and directing additional resources to key areas to continue to improve health and social outcomes.

The major focus in this portfolio has been on improving access to health services for rural and regional Australia, including the establishment of a rural multi-purpose health and family services network, worth $24.3 million over four years; more support for older Australians to stay in their homes through the $269 million `staying at home' initiative; from next year, free annual influen za vaccines for all Australians aged over 65 years, a package worth more than $20 million a year; improved access to Medicare refunds through another 200 pharmacies, at a cost of $10.2 million; and $165 million for the National Health and Medical Research Council.

I digress for a moment to note that, under the Labor Party's forward projections in their last budget, the National Health and Medical Research Council would have had no funds for new research. I invite the Labor Party to look at their forward projections. There were no funding increases. We are giving a record level of funding for the NHMRC.

Other measures include $95.5 million over five years for demand reduction and harm minimisation initiatives as part of the government's national illicit drug strategy; assisting 100 overseas trained doctors to gain skills in Australia in return for working in rural and remote areas for five yearsâ

talk.start.para: âOh!
â`Oh!', Senator Crowley said. That is a new initiative. The Labor government had 13 years to do something about it, and they did nothing.
âRubbish!
âSenator Forshaw!

âThere will be another $6.1 million over three years for the implementation of tobacco harm minimisation initiatives. More specifically, this government has made a major commitment to addressing the unacceptable level of disadvantage suffered by Australia's indigenous people. In the health area, the government will spend an extra $72 million over the next four years, including $30.5 million as part of the public and preventative health package. This is to address the urgent health needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

answer.para: Under the Labor Party, the health problems of Aboriginal people got worse; they went backwards. We are injecting a major, massive increase of $72 million over the next four years. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have urgent health needs and we are addressing them.

In a two-pronged attack, more than $22.6 million over four years will be spent on addressing the unacceptably high level of infectious disease in Australia's indigenous population. The funding also includes a national immunisation program specifically targeting respiratory illnesses, including influenza. An extra $7.9 million will be spent on capital works to maintain health clinics and facilities in remote indigenous communities. There are many other initiatives that I would like to expound on. I would welcome a further question from Senator Payne so that I can spell out further initiatives.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI noted particularly the minister's response on research initiatives and indigenous health care. Are there any other aspects of the budget initiatives that the minister could outline to assist Australians and their families?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Payne.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner!

âSenator Faulkner may be interested to know that, under the Labor government, Professor Feachem did a study in relation to HIV and STD in the Northern Territory in particular, and appealed for more funds to be spent. What did the Labor Party do?
âNothing, absolutely nothing.

âNothing; they did nothing about it. We are putting money into that. We are also putting $7.9 million into capital works to maintain health clinics and facilities in remote indigenous communities. Labor had 13 years to address the many problems that were allowed to fester under the management of many of the same old faces over there. We hear about all the things they would have done if they had been given a few more years.

answer.para: Labor not only completely failed indigenous Australians; they failed all Australians. We were left, as you know, with a $10.3 billion deficit which we have managed to clean up in two years. We are taking a new approach to health and it is the right approach. (Time expired)

Senator ALSTON

talk.start.para: âDuring the last session, the Senate resolved that I table a report by independent auditors, chartered accountants and management consultants, Arthur Andersen, on the submission by the ABC on the cost of funding the national broadcaster's digital transition entitled Evaluation of the ABC's digitisation strategy. I did not table the document at the time on the basis that it was a confidential report obtained by the government for the purpose of consideration of issues related to the budget. As the budget has now been released, I consider it appropriate that the document be tabled. I hereby table the relevant report.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senators Chapman and Senator Lightfoot today, relating to the 1998-99 Budget.

The surplus that has been trumpeted here today in the answers to those questions was built on the back of cuts to health, nursing homes, education, child care, jobs and industry support. The sad thing about those cuts is that, whilst this budget puts some pennies back, it leaves the pounds away. This is a cut that has been borne by families, by workers and by the Australian community, and there is no real gain for them in this budget. The pity is that it was not necessary. Those cuts did not need to occur. Left to the parameters that we set as we went out of government, the budget would have grown, with the changes that we had announced, to being in surplus at this time. That is important to keep in mind when we debate what has so far allegedly been achieved by the Treasurer.

Today we are not so much debating a budget as we are talking about a May economic statement. We know that the real pain and the real issues are down the track, lurking in wait for the Australian electorate as the government announces its so-called tax reform package, a tax reform package that will almost certainly include a goods and services taxâa regressive taxâwhich will be applied to all Australians irrespective of income. That will be another thimble and pea trick. It will offer tax cuts to middle Australia bought on the backs of all Australians. It will give back less than it takes from the pockets of ordinary Australians.

We know too that the budget surplus that has been trumpeted here today is a surplus that will remain intact for as long as it suits the government. They will use and plunder that surplus when it comes to giving give aways and pork barrelling to those wish-list groups that it favours in the Australian electorate. That is the truth about this budget. Brace yourselves for an election campaign. Brace yourselves for a fist full of dollars election campaign. Brace yourselves for a thimble and pea trick.

The government tells us a number of things about this budget but it also interestingly omits to say a number of things that are important. To get a real picture of the outcome, you need to know that this budget forecasts that export growth will decline. It forecasts that investment levels in the Australian economy will fall. It forecasts that consumer spending for the next year will be down. It forecasts that investment in housing will also drop considerably. It announces in its forward projections that business investment will fall and it discloses in its report that research and development investment in Australia has fallen through the floor. It does those things on the back of a forecast that national savings, the much trumpeted element of this budget, is in fact in decline as well.

Unemployment in this budget is just unbelievable. It is stuck in any case, according to the projections, at a very rubbery eight per cent, not underpinned by the economic growth that the economy needs to sustain the figure. It is a most unbelievable forecast. As well, we know in this budget that the current account deficit for the nation is reeling out of control and has virtually doubled in the last two years from $17 billion to now being a projected current account deficit of $31 billion and that foreign debt has leapt by $26 billion to now rank at the highest in the history of this nationâ$222 billion. That is $26 billion above the level of when the now government, when in opposition, rolled its so-called `debt truck' around Australia to declaim the previous government. Under this government, it has risen by $26 billion.

It ought to be remembered that the cuts made in the earlier budgets took $36 billion out of public health; it has only put $2 billion back. In the previous budget, $500 million were taken out of nursing homes; nothing goes back. Cuts of $800 were made to child care; not a cent goes back. Cuts of $3 billion were made to universities; nothing goes back. The jobs programs were cut by $1.8 billion, while youth employment has risen unemployment by 27.1 per cent: a give and take budget. Now wait for the big whammyâthe goods and services tax.

In the election that the Prime Minister announced to his party room yesterday, you can be sure of one thing from Labor; you will not have a goods and services tax. You can be sure of one thing from the government; you will have a goods and services tax and, while it will be coated by lucrative tax cuts, look at what you really save. Australia will be the loser. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat humbug we have heard from Senator Cook today. We hear it every time he gets up in the Senate on some matter he wishes to raise in response to questions that have been asked and answers given during question time, but today certainly takes the cake.

speech.para: The most important priority of a federal government is to maintain a nation's finances in a sound position. Governments cannot do anything else unless the nation's finances are sound. All the other demands that are made on government for initiatives here and action there are dependent on the country and in particular the government finances themselves being in a sound position.

But that is a dictum that was completely ignored by the Labor Party when they were in government because the philosophy of the Labor Party was to spend, to borrow and to taxânothing else; no responsibility at all as far as financial management was concerned. Let us hear what Mr Gary Evans, the shadow Treasurer said yesterday when he was interviewed on 4QR, in answer to a question that was put in this form:
I can't help but asking if you could have done all these marvellous things with the economy.

These are, of course, the things that the Liberal-National government have done in the last two yearsâdelivered a surplus and reduced unemployment to the lowest rate since 1990 at 8 per cent. `Why didn't you?' the interviewer says to Gary Evans. This is the shadow Treasurer's response, and I quote:
Well, we wereâI mean, we ran into the problem of the recession of 1989-90 and 1990-91 with high interest rates and all the restâ

that we all remember with a shudder. What he forgot to say, of course, was that it was a deliberately induced recession by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, who described it as the `recession we had to have.' It was deliberately induced by raising interest rates through the roof and sending small business and home owners through the floor. Small business overdraft rates were 17 to 20 per cent during that periodâthat is the sort of financial management we saw under the Labor Party, which absolutely sent our economy through the floor.

Over the last two years this government has acted responsibly to restore sound financial management and to lay the basis for economic growth in this country. As a result of that, we have in the budget delivered last night a $2.7 billion budget surplus projected for the 1998-1999 financial year. That is important, not only because it provides a sound basis for the private sector to develop and grow and provide jobs and all the other benefits for the community, but also because it allows us to pay off that other dreadful legacy of the Labor governmentâour massively accumulated government debt. There was something of the order of $97 billion accumulated under 13 years of Laborâabout $80 billion of which was accumulated during their last five years in office.

talk.start.para: âA disgrace. A national disgrace.

âAn absolute disgrace in terms of economic managementâthat is right, Senator Lightfoot. Now, because we are generating a surplus, we can start to pay that debt off. Already, we will have succeeded, by the end of 1998-99, in paying off some $31 billion of that debt. With further privatisation of Telstra, over the next three or four years beyond that, we will have that debt down to $23 billion dollarsâa massive turnaround and a massive success on the part of a Liberal-National Party government. That not only restores international confidence in the Australian economy but also, most importantly, it frees up money in the annual budget so our budgetary position on an annual basis is even better.

speech.para: Under Labor, of course, more was being paid out each year by the government in interest than they were spending on defence or education because of the massive debt that they had accumulated. We will get that down to $23 billion and this will free up $5 billion or $6 billion a year out of the annual budget for either further tax reductions and benefits thereby to the Australian community or, if areas of need are identified, provide extra expenditure in those areas of need. The Labor Party fails to recognise this basic fundamental of economic management. As I said, their whole approach is to spend and worry about it later. They will either borrow the money to cover the spending or they will raise taxes to cover the spending; but they do not analyse things properly, they do not get to the nub of issues as far as sound financial management is concerned.

Now we have got the lowest home mortgage rates that Australia has experienced since 1970, falling from 10.5 per cent down to 6.5 per centâworth $3,800 a year for the average home buyer. These are the benefits delivered by this government over the lastâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn the context of the questions that Senator Kemp answered on the budget, there has been a great deal of focus on the budget surplus of $2.7 billion. There has also been a great deal of focus in past years on how that has been achieved. We all know of the massive cuts to state funding, health, education, aged care, child care and many more areas. Suffice it to say, it was not necessary to cut to that degree and to the extent to which you did. But the focus on the budget surplus and the contribution to the level of government debt is only part of a very important story. Senator Cook quite rightly raised the issue of what is an extremely worrying figure in respect of the current account deficit.

speech.para: Senator Cook also raised the issue of total foreign debt, which is also of great concern, given that it has increased by some $26 billion. I looked through budget paper No. 1 in an attempt to find some reference to total foreign debt, particularly given that this government asked question after question on the subject during their period in oppositionâin fact, they had a debt truck roaming the country. And surprise, surprise! There is no reference whatsoever to total foreign debt in budget paper No. 1. But, of course, there is extensive reference to the current account deficit and the need for savingânot just government saving, but an increase in total national savings.

If we look at the table on page 1.12 we see the government's projections are for a decrease in private saving and a decrease in gross national saving. In the context of our current account deficit, which is increasing rapidly, this is an extremely worrying economic trend. It is one that Mr Costello and Senator Kemp quite conveniently attempt to evade as much as possible.

If we look at the budget papers on 3.11, in respect of private savingâwhich the government argues should increaseâthere is a reference to a prospect and a suggestion of factors that improve the outlook for private saving. There is a reference to the superannuation guaranteeâthat was an important Labor initiative. There is a reference to the savings rebateâand that, if anything, has cut private saving. There is a reference to tax reform and the prospect that it has the potential to enhance private savingâthat, presumably, is a reference to the foreshadowed introduction of a goods and services tax. The argument is that, if you tax consumption through a goods and services taxâsorry, it is now called a BIBIT or a BOBIT; the government is not anxious to use the name GSTâ

talk.start.para: âDo you blame us?

âBOBIT or BIBIT: it will be interesting to see which one you use in the election period. The argument is that if you tax consumption through a GST saving will go up. There is absolutely no evidence that that will happen. I must say that the next paragraph did surprise me. It says:

speech.para: Finally, quite apart from these policy influences, demographic change over the next decade or so is likely to see a rise in the proportion of the population age groups which historically have been high savers and a decline in younger, low-saving age cohorts.

That is in Budget Paper No. 1 at 3.11. We all know that this country faces an ageing population, and I would have thought it was common knowledge that an ageing population with a increasing proportion who are retired are net dis-savers. So how on earth that can be referred to as a factor that will lead to a very important increase in private saving is beyond me.
Lastly, in Budget Paper No. 1 at 2.7, there is continual reference to Japan:

The outlook for Japan is a matter of concern. Not only is Japan heavily exposed to regional developments, its domestic economy is experiencing substantial weaknesses and shows no sign of an early turnaround.

Well, thank goodness, because we know why Japan has significant economic problems: it introduced a GST at a rate of three per cent some five years ago and it increased that goods and services tax to a rate of five per cent last April. It has absolutely flattened the economy.
There is extensive reference to the strength of the US. What is one outstanding feature of the economy of the United States? It does not have a goods and services tax.

talk.start.para: âI am delighted that Senator Cook is still here, because we are eternal optimists on this side of the chamber and we are quite sure that at some stage in the future Senator Cook will try to redeem his economic credentials by eventually apologising for misleading this chamber just prior to the 1996 election by saying that the government's budget was in surplus. Senator Cook, we do actually live in hope that the longer you stay in the chamberâ
âWould you like to address the chair, please?

âYes, Madam Deputy President, I most certainly would. On this side of the chamber we are optimistic enough to think that the longer Senator Cook stays in this chamber, the more chance there is that he might admit that he made a terrible mistake and that he did mislead this chamber by saying that the previous government had a budget that was in surplus prior to the 1996 election when we know that in fact they left us with an enormous deficit.

speech.para: Senator Cook talks about the surplus we are creating being built on the spending cuts to a range of people. In fact, the surplus this government has brought forward is even more marvellous because it has been built on the back of your enormous deficit. If Senator Cook and Senator Sherry want to claim some economic credentials in this chamber, people only have to look at their efforts over the previous time they were in government to see that they have none at all. Nobody believes what the members of the opposition say with respect to this budget.

If you really want to get some accurate comment about the budget that was put down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) last night, you really need to have a look at some third party endorsements from people outside of this place who actually make comments about the budget with some authority. We only need to go as far as the Business Council of Australia and its president, Stan Wallis, who is well regarded by people on the other side of this chamber. He says:
This is a budget that is absolutely right for the times. More importantly, the Howard government has honoured its promise to the Australian people by delivering a budget surplus.

That is something that Senator Cook could never claim. He could never claim to have honoured his promise, because he promised that the budget was in surplus when in fact it was in deficit. Mr Wallis also said that this budget makes sure that we can keep a check on interest rates and inflation. Anybody who remembers the Hawke-Keating period of government will know how devastating high interest rates were to businesses in Australia.

The National Farmers Federation themselves have commented this morning that `the drop of 2.5 per cent in interest rates since March 1996 that has applied to most farmers has been worth $450 million in reduced interest payments for farmers.' On top of that, the provisional tax uplift factor has been further reduced. When the previous government was in place, the provisional tax uplift factor was 10 per cent, and now we have guaranteed that this will be reduced a further percentage pointâand this will provide major savings to farmers as well.

Let us go to the comments of some other people. People have talked about the effect on tourism. The chairman of the Tourism Task Force, Mr John Brown, said that the money that has been allocated could not have come at a better time; that the minister, Andrew Thomson, deserves the applause of the industry and its one million workers for this budget result.

talk.start.para: âIs that the former Labor Party minister?

âI am not sure if it is the former Labor Party minister, but the name, John Brown, is very familiar. The housing industry says that the government's commitment to a substantial budget surplus is `the right defence for Australia against the Asian economic fallout.' Then you can go to those people who really count, older Australians, the National President of the Association of Independent Retirees, Maureen Kingston, says that she is `delighted that the government has listened to the voice of independent retirees who have endeavoured to provide their own income in retirement and made sure that they are not a burden on this government when it comes to providing an income in retirement for their own good.' (Time expired)

âI also wish to take note of the answers to questions on the budget. Those on Senator Ferguson's side certainly are eternal optimists. Today's performance seemed to be an example that if you assert the same proposition strongly and often enough, some people eventually will believe you. But people are concerned with both the social costs and the methods of achieving this surplus. None of that was addressed today by the government.

speech.para: If we look at the costs of this surplus over the term of this government, we come up with figures, contrary to Senator Payne's question about the boost in health, showing a decline of $1.62 billion spending in health. We have a decline of around $400 million spending in aged and community care at the same time as the nursing home debacle; we have a decline of $1.5 billion in employment programs; we have a decline of around $3 billion in education; and we have a decline of around $800 million in child care. People in the community are concerned about these things. People want their services back from this government.

It is incredible that in this budget, as was canvassed during question time with some of the questions, at a time when we have a GDP growth forecast declining from 3Â¾ per cent down to three per cent, the government predicts that employment growth will increase from its forecast of 1Â¼ per cent to 1Â¾ per cent. This is simply incredible, even with the low participation rate, where the government has been driving 100,000 people out of the job market to achieve the still unacceptable level of unemployment remainingâand predicted to remainâat around eight per cent.

I am reminded of this government member's position at the time of Working Nation. We were criticised about the nature of some of our employment programs during Working Nation. At least these people were still in the job market. This government is driving people out of the job market to reduce their unemployment levelsâit is incredible.

At the same time, we have this government claiming the benefits of low inflation rates and the benefits for people in home ownership. What we did not hear today is that there is a decline in the home ownership growth; it is contracting. Why is it contracting? Because to own a home and to pay off a mortgage you need a job, and this government is not concerned about employment. Employment is a non-core promise; it is not important.

At this stage we need to be concentrating on growth. We need a higher level of growth if we are going to do anything about unemployment. We cannot get ourselves into a position where we solve our balance of payments problems unless we start looking at issues such as skills, infrastructure, innovation and net exports. We need to be doing more than just the 1Â½ pages of comments on the millennium bug. Sure, it is an important problem, but we need to be doing far more in relation to Australian industry than that and additional assistance to tourism. We will not generate employment for our future work force.

Let us look at what the budget did do for Australian industry. There is nothing in the budget to relieve the pain that Australian industry is going through at the moment. Instead, the government has delivered the following: a $300,000 cut to the anti-dumping system at a time when manufacturers are facing unprecedented international pressure with the Asian economic crisis; and a major underspend of R&D START program. In the 1998-99 period, there will be a further 2.36 shortfall according to the budget papers. Where is innovation?

Not one cent has been set aside, despite the Prime Minister's promises, for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry assistance package. It must not have been a core promise. There is a continuing decline in support for manufacturers from $542 million in the 1997-98 period to $405 million in 2001-2002. There is the abolition of the shipbuilding bounty in 1998-99. There is a collapse in support for information technology. This area, where the government has claimed major initiatives, is going from $84 million to only $6 million over four years. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Sen Julian
Senator McGAURAN
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: âI would also like to join this debate in regard to the budget. Like Senator Ferguson, I am also bewildered that the day after the budget is delivered back on track in the black with a reduction of the $10.5 billion deficit, the opposition happen to bring out as its lead attack in the first question, Senator Cook. Senator Cook, as we all knowâSenator Ferguson made the pointâhas no credibility to discuss budget surpluses or budget matters at all, when he was party to the cover-up of the previous government's $10.5 billion deficit.

speech.para: Even his shadow minister, Mr Gareth Evans, has come clean on the matter. He has told us, `Yes, there was a $10.5 billion deficit.' So why doesn't Senator Cook, before he makes comments on this government's budget, come in here and apologise for his cover-up? Then we may turn our attention to some of his questions. He came in and quoted the Treasurer's past comments in 1995. He quoted them quite correctly because they were good comments in relation to the current account.

The current account deficit of this government is far apart and different from the previous government's. The difference is that your current account deficit was a higher percentage of GDPâ6Â½ per cent and rising and dangerously risingâwhile our current account deficit is in fact falling.

talk.start.para: âIt's getting worse.
âIt is around the five per cent mark, Senator Sherry. That is the difference. But more than that; the current account deficit has takenâ
âWhat about foreign debt?

âI will get on to foreign debt. The current account deficit has been affected of course by the Asian economic crisis. So it is not an import-driven current account deficit as it was in your time, affecting interest rates and affecting the inflation rate. Rather, we haveâand how could we avoid itâa current account deficit affected by our exports. That is the second difference.

speech.para: The third one is, as the Treasurer has said, if you had a current account deficit problemâ we do not deny that it is an ongoing problem that does require managementâthen what is the first thing you do? What is the first advice you would get? It would be to bring your budget into surplus, and that is exactly what we did and that is exactly what you did not do. That is the answer to the current account deficit and it is very similar in relation to the foreign debt.

The foreign debt has levelled out. It has not jumped from $30 billion in 1983 when you first entered government to around the $200 billion markâthat was the jump in your 13 years. It has increased slightly; it has in fact levelled out. How do you tackle foreign debt of this level? You introduce a surplus budget; you get your own government expenditure and revenue into order. And that is what we have done.

In fact, the foreign debt has also decreased as a percentage of GDP. They are very good figures. They have been achieved with no tax increases and on time, as has been said, even with the Asian economic firestorm which is engulfing the whole world. As a result, we have the lowest interest rate since pre-Whitlam days. We have the lowest inflation rate since pre-Whitlam days. We have the first true, underlying surplus since pre-Whitlam days. And we have the lowest unemployment rate since the recession. That is still an ongoing problem that requires management, but it has been wound back since the worst days of your government. We will not stop thereâthat was the first leg of our journey. The second leg of our journey is to reduce debt.

I want to pick up two points with regard to Senator Cook's hackneyed comment that this surplus has been achieved on the back of cuts in health and social security. They were fair and necessary cuts, and the market and the community judged them as such. Also, Senator Cook should speak to former Senator Kernot about this, because she says that the reforms introduced by this government, particularly in the social security area, will not be changed if the Labor Party gets into government. That is an endorsement of our changes and it utterly contradicts what Sena tor Cook and Senator Jacinta Collins are trying to sell here today.

talk.start.para: âPetitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.
We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:
Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

talk.start.para: Senator Margetts(from 116 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that we, as residents of the State of Victoria, urge the government to:
reject moves to cut the funding of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and instead maintain funding in real terms.
recognise and maintain the role of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as a comprehensive, mainstream and independent media organisation, and not just a complementary service to commercial media.
recognise the ABC Charter as a valuable instrument for the expression of Australian cultural life that should not be devalued as a result of economic and political considerations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: The President(from 87 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service was `operational' and accepted responsibility for disabilities resulting from that service. However, government departments are still resorting to old, and inventing new excuses, to deny the above 3 points.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate acts to help remove the injustice of 40 years and fully recognise R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age' as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

For permanent protection of old-growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. maximise use of readily-available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal-waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter-grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

Dear Parliamentary Secretary
I refer to the following amendments of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 398

speech.para: Regulations 13.2 to 13.4 add further sets of fees to Schedule 9 of the Principal Regulations. While the Explanatory Statement accurately describes the effect of these provisions, it does not provide information on the basis on which the fees have been set.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 399

speech.para: New subregulation 16J(1) requires the Secretary to consider an application for a drug to be designated an orphan drug but does not specify that this task should be carried out within any particular time. In this context, s.60(4) of the enabling Act and subregulation 48(4) of the Principal Regulations provide that a failure to reconsider within 60 days is taken to be a confirmation of the original decision. The Committee suggests that a similar provision may be appropriate in this case.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 400

speech.para: The definition of mainstream media in r.5B is unclear. For one thing, it refers to any magazine or newspaper for consumers but does not indicate what class of person is included within the notion of consumers. Does it refer to the consumers of therapeutic goods or to consumers of other products? The definition might also be regarded as unnecessarily broad as it would, for instance, apparently encompass a magazine for consumers containing only a range of competitions.

New rr.5K and 5L permit the Secretary to vary the conditions of an approval, or to withdraw an approval. The Committee notes that those decisions are subject to review by ministerial and AAT review. Subregulation 5M(6), however, provides that a request for a review of the Secretary's decision does not affect the operation of that decision. Neither rr.5K or 5L prevent the Secretary from issuing a notice of variation or withdrawal with immediate effect, which could have unfair financial implications for the intending advertiser of the relevant product.

Regulation 19 provides for the fees that are to be charged on an application for approval of an advertisement, but the Explanatory Statement does not indicate the basis on which those fees have been set. Furthermore, paragraph (c) of the regulation refers to an advertorial, which is presumably something other than an advertisement, and for which there is no warrant in the regulations for charging fees since advertorials do not need approval under r.5F.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 Nos 398-401

speech.para: The Committee notes that these four sets of Regulations were all made on the same day. This would appear to be a duplication of effort.

All four sets of regulations provide for important matters affecting the general administration of therapeutic goods. These appear to be of sufficient importance that it may be more appropriate to address them through amendment of the enabling Act, where the changes would be subject to full parliamentary debate. In this context one of the Committee's terms of reference is to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

The Committee notes that both the enabling Act and the Regulations provide for eventual review of decisions by the AAT. Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer to your letter of 11 March 1998 relating to Statutory Rules 1997 Nos 398-401. The following information is provided in response to the matters raised in your correspondence.

para.inline: "Regulations 13.2 to 13.4 add further sets of fees to Schedule 9 of the Principal Regulation. While the Explanatory Statement accurately describes the effect of these provisions, it does not provide information on the basis on which the fees have been set."

speech.para: . The fees have been set in line with the Government's decision for the Therapeutic Goods Administration [TGA] to move to 100% cost recovery of its activities. These new fees represent the role of the TGA in carrying out evaluation and certification on behalf of the European Commission under the Mutual Recognition Agreement between Australia and the European Commission. It will enable Australian Manufacturers to mark their products so they can be sold without further evaluation in European countries.

. 13.2 Introduces a new fee [$5,660] for the review of data submitted by the sponsor of a therapeutic device to establish that software meets specifications. This fee is consistent with the fee already included in Schedule 9 Item 6 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations at p.76 for the review of other categories of data.

. 13.3(a) Introduces a new fee [$2,465] for the evaluation of overseas reports and summary data for therapeutic devices. This fee is consistent with the fee for the review of data under Schedule 9 Item 5(A) of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations.

. 13.3(b) Introduces a new fee [$1,070] for the evaluation of overseas reports or data submitted in support of an application where the sponsor submits more than one application at the same time and the data submitted is sufficiently common to allow simultaneous evaluation of each of the applications. This fee is in line with the fee applicable under Therapeutic Goods Regulation 45(11)(a).

. 13.4 Introduces a new fee [$2,800] for the evaluation of data submitted to support changes to software for an existing registered device. This fee is consistent with the charge for review of biocompatibility data as specified in Item 7(a)(c).

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 399

"New subregulation 16J(1) required the Secretary to consider an application for a drug to be designated an orphan drug but does not specify that this task should be carried out within any particular time. In this context, s. 60(4) of the enabling Act and subregulation 48(4) of the Principal Regulations provide that a failure to reconsider within 60 days is taken to be a confirmation of the original decision. The Committee suggests that a similar provision may be appropriate in this case."

speech.para: . This regulation relates to the new orphan drugs program which is modelled on the US Food and Drug Administration [FDA] Orphan Drugs Program. The arrangements to apply to the Australian program have been agreed between the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association [APMA] and the Therapeutic Goods Administration [TGA].
. The time taken to evaluate products seeking `orphan' status is as yet unknown and is affected to a significant degree by the time it takes to obtain relevant data from the FDA.

. The APMA and TGA have agreed to review the implementation of the program at the end of the first twelve months of operation [ie. December 1998] with a view to incorporating appropriate statutory time frames for evaluation in the regulations.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulation (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 400

"The definition of mainstream media in r.5B is unclear. For one thing, it refers to any magazine or newspaper for consumers but does not indicate what class of person is included within the notion of consumers. Does it refer to the consumers of therapeutic goods or to consumers of other products? The definition might also be regarded as unnecessarily broad as it would, for instance, apparently encompass a magazine for consumers containing only a range of competitions."

speech.para: . The Macquarie Dictionary definition of `consumer' is "one who or that which consumes" and "one who uses a commodity or service". In this context the commodity or services is therapeutic goods.

. A `consumer' is anyone who may consume therapeutic goods other than health professionals. Regulation 4 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations defines health professionals as a class of people to whom advertisements may be directed without being subject to this part of the Regulations.
. The definition of "mainstream media" in the Regulations parallels the arrangements used by the Australian Publishers Bureau when clearing print media advertisements.

. The definition was included to ensure that arrangements for the clearance of print media advertisements are the same as those previously applied by the Media Council of Australia and the Australian Publishers Bureau.

. The Media Council of Australiaâwhich comprised all major print and broadcast media proprietorsâadministered the arrangements for the development and ongoing maintenance of the code of advertising for therapeutic goods up until the end of 1996.

para.inline: "New rr.5K and 5L permit the Secretary to vary the conditions of an approval, or to withdraw an approval. The Committee notes that those decisions are subject to review by ministerial and AAT review. Subregulation 5M(6), however, provides that a request for a review of the Secretary's decision does not affect the operation of that decision. Neither rr.5K or 5L prevent the Secretary from issuing a notice of variation of withdrawal with immediate effect, which could have unfair financial implications for the intending advertiser of the relevant product."

speech.para: . If an advertisement fails to comply with the conditions of approval, the Secretary has the right to withdraw or vary that approval.
. This regulation recognises the inappropriateness of allowing a breach to continue [which, for example may harm public health] whilst an appeal against a decision was initiated.

. The Nutritional Foods Association of Australia and the Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia both agreed that it would not be appropriate to allow breaches of the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code to continue whilst an appeal is under way.

para.inline: "Regulation 19 provides for the fees that are to be charged on an application for approval of an advertisement, but the Explanatory Statement does not indicate the basis on which those fees have been set. Furthermore, paragraph (c) of the regulation refers to an advertorial, which is presumably something other than an advertisement, and for which there is no warrant in the regulations for charging fees since advertorials do not need approval under r.5F."

speech.para: . The fees and charges specified in these Regulations are identical to those charged by the Australian Publishers Bureau for the clearance of advertisements under the previous arrangements auspiced by the Media Council of Australia.

. TGA is aware that the term `advertorial' at Item 17(c) of Schedule 9 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations already exists within the definition of advertisement in the Therapeutic Goods Act. Schedule 9 will, as a matter of course, be updated before the end of the financial year to reflect new fees and charges, and at this time the word `advertorials' will also be removed from the schedule.

. An `advertorial' is a form of advertising. As the guidelines for Advertising Therapeutic Goods to the Public explain, "Advertorial is a term used by advertisers and publishers to describe the situation where what might appear to be bona fide editorial comment, is in fact an advertisement for a particular product".

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 Nos 398-401
"The Committee notes that these four sets of Regulations were all made on the same day. This would appear to be a duplication of effort."

"All four sets of regulations provide for important matters affecting the general administration of therapeutic goods. These appear to be of sufficient importance that it may be more appropriate to address them through amendment of the enabling Act where the changes would be subject to full parliamentary debate. In this context one of the Committee's terms of reference is to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment."

speech.para: . Three of the four regulations [398, 400 and 401] all refer to similar subject matter contained within the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code.

. Regulation 400 underpins the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code in regulation. This measure was undertaken at the request of industry. The Nutritional Foods Association of Australia and the Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia wrote to the Government in October 1997 requesting that the Code be underpinned in regulation as a matter of priority. This request was undertaken.

. The Committee's attention is drawn to the fact that the arrangements now provided for in the regulations have been in place since 1977. The effect of including these arrangements in regulations will be to provide greater transparency and accountability, including rights of appeal.

. At the same time, certain other measures required clarification. These were intentionally presented as separate regulations [398 and 401] to distinguish them from the pre-existing Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code. It would not be appropriate to amend the enabling Act because these are amendments to existing regulations.

para.inline: "The Committee notes that both the enabling Act and the Regulations provide for eventual reviews of decisions by the AAT. The Committee would appreciate your assurance that the present four sets of regulations will not affect adversely the conduct or the outcome of any case presently before the AAT by a person challenging a decision under the legislation."

speech.para: . The current Regulations clarify the existing law. There is currently a definition of `drugs' in the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under Regulation 2 as follows:
"drugs" means:

(a) therapeutic goods that are presented to achieve, or are likely to achieve, their principal intended action by pharmacological, chemical, immunological or metabolic means in or on the body of a person or an animal"
. Any claim in an advertisement that a product coming within the definition of `drug' is `drug-free' would therefore be inconsistent with the terms of the existing legislation.
. The changes effected by the four (4) sets of Regulation should not adversely affect the conduct or outcome of any case presently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

. There is only one relevant case presently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that relates to the subject matter of Statutory Rule 401. A challenge has been mounted against the decision of a delegate of the Secretary to issue a notice under Regulation 7 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations to prevent a person publishing an advertisement that drugs are `drug free'. This matter is still before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and action taken to amend the Regula tions should not affect the ability of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review the delegate's actions to determine whether the issue of the notice should have occurred. Similarly, the amendments to the regulations should not affect the outcome of the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the matter.
. However, the new regulations will, as of the date of the amendment, preclude any advertisement from being published with a claim that drugs are `drug free'.
Yours sincerely
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services

speech.para: Your advice in respect of the basis of fees met the concerns of the Committee. para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 197 No 399

It would be appreciated if you could write to the Committee as soon as the review is completed.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 400

speech.para: The Committee wrote to you about the clarity of drafting of these Regulations. Following your reply the Committee remains concerned about the quality of drafting and would appreciate your advice that you have asked the APMA and TGA review to address particularly this question and to suggest changes which would make the Regulations easier to understand and apply by those affected by them. The Committee suggests that if a body with the expertise and experience of the Committee has difficulty with the drafting then those people directly affected, who would not usually be lawyers, would have similar difficulties.

In this context the Committee notes that the last reprint of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations appears to have been on 8 March 1995 and was 86 pages long. Since then there have been 15 separate amendments of the Regulations amounting to 112 pages, not including Statutory Rules 1996 No 25, which was disallowed by the House of Representatives on 10 September 1996. At present, therefore, amendments of the Regulations are longer than the reprinted Regulations themselves. This must be confusing for users, who would find it difficult to know whether they are complying with the law. The Committee would appreciate your advice that you have asked for a reprint to be produced as a matter of priority.

The Committee also wrote to you about provisions under which the Secretary may withdraw or vary an approval. These decisions are subject to merits review but may take effect immediately, with what the Committee suggested could be unfair results. Your reply referred to the inappropriate consequences of allowing breaches to continue while an appeal is initiated. The Committee suggest, however, that the fundamental point is that there is a difference of opinion between the Secretary and the person affected about what is a breach. The decision of the AAT may well be that no breach has occurred. In such a case the advertiser may therefore lose business because the approval was wrongly withdrawn. Nevertheless, the Committee is prepared to accept the present position on the basis of an assurance from you that appropriate financial compensation will be paid to advertisers if the AAT decides in their favour.

The Committee also wrote to you about fees in these Regulations and about an apparent invalid reference to advertorials . Your reply indicated that the fees and charges were the same as the previous arrangements. These fees are, however, now provided for in the Regulations and the Committee assumes that they are based on cost recovery, because there does not appear to be legal authority, for instance, for the fees to raise revenue. The Committee is grateful for your advice that the reference to advertorials will be deleted before the end of the present financial year.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 Nos 398â401

speech.para: The Committee asked about the need to make four separate sets of Regulations on the same day. Your reply advises that three of them (Nos 398, 400 and 401) all refer to similar subject matter but that they were intentionally presented separately. Your advice is that No 400 does not represent a change in the existing arrangements, except apparently for the right of review, but that Nos 398 and 401 do. Presumably No 399 also changes the existing law. The Committee does not press the point relating to duplication of effort but points out that sound public administration usually does not require the Governor-General to make four sets of statutory rules, with the same title, made under the same enabling Act, on the same day, with gazettal on the same day, amending the same Principal Regulations.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 Nos 398â401

speech.para: The Committee wrote to you suggesting that the four sets of Regulations are sufficiently important that it may be more appropriate to address the matters with which they deal through amendment of the enabling Act, when the changes would be subject to full parliamentary debate. The Committee advised you that one of its terms of reference is to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. Your reply dealt with this question briefly, advising that it would not be appropriate to amend the enabling Act because these are amendments of existing regulations.

With great respect, your advice lacks merit. For the purposes of the Committee's terms of reference it is irrelevant whether an instrument amends an existing instrument. The Committee's mandate to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for an Act is an important safeguard for parliamentary propriety and one which the Committee is especially vigilant to enforce. The very first Report of the Committee in 1932 dealt with this aspect of its terms of reference and the Committee has received undertakings since that date from Ministers to place matters, initially included in legislative instruments, in Bills. The attitude of the Committee is this respect is expressed by a reported quotation from Sir Robert Garran, whose opinion was that the Committee was the most important in Parliament because "its duty was to see that Parliament ran the country with legislation not the Executive with regulations and ordinances", Senate Hansard, 17 August 1971, p.195. Sir Robert was a counsel who helped draft the Constitution and the first Commonwealth Solicitor-General.

As you know, the subject matter of No 401 is contentious and is the subject of considerable public concern. The Committee has noted your further advice that you have established a committee of review to examine the issues contained in No 401, and that you intend to table the results of that review in Parliament. The Committee would therefore appreciate your advice that following this review the material in No 401 will be included in a Bill. Such a undertaking would enable the Committee to remove its notice of disallowance.

The Committee's actions in respect of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, like its actions in respect of all legislative instruments, are directed to protect personal rights and parliamentary propriety. The Committee does not deal with policy and does not have a view on the policy aspects of No 401. Its aim is to protect the rights of Parliament.

You have advised that there is only one present AAT case that relates to the subject matter of No 401 and that the present Regulations should not affect the ability of the AAT to decide whether a notice should have been issued. Here again the Committee assumes that if the matter is decided against the delegate of the Secretary then suitable financial compensation will be paid.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

Chairman, Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances

speech.para: As you are aware, there has been a longstanding co-regulatory approach to the advertising of therapeutic goods in the broadcast media, and under the proposed new arrangements, industry will be responsible for pre-clearance of print advertisements to the public.

The industry organisations, the Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia (PMAA) and the Nutritional Foods Association of Australia (NFAA) who will be responsible for granting approval for advertisements, requested that authority be given to the Secretary to withdraw or vary an approval in specific circumstancesâsuch as where an advertisement has been granted approval based on false or incorrect information provided by the product sponsor/advertiser. This power granted to the Secretary is important for ensuring that the industry organisations can uphold their delegated powers under the law and properly administer the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code. This power also ensures that there is consistency in application of the Code across the industry. Without this regulatory provision, a product sponsor who did not comply for example with the conditions for an advertisement but who was not an industry organisation member could continue to run the advertisement. Similar action by an industry organisation member would lead to significant sanctions.

I would like to stress that the power of the Secretary to withdraw or alter approval for an advertisement, would only be used in exceptional circumstances and following discussions with sponsors and advertisers. Also, there is certainly no impediment to a sponsor/advertiser publishing another advertisement for the same product that does meet the requirements of the Code.

To ensure that the system of coregulation for print advertising is working effectively, I have asked that the effectiveness of this arrangement be reviewed within 12 months of implementation of these regulations.

In relation to the appeal of decisions by the Secretary, the arrangements proposed by the regulations are in accordance with normal appeal arrangements to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Under these arrangements a decision which is appealed against in the AAT remains in place until the AAT reverses the decision, or unless an applicant successfully applies to the AAT for a stay of the original decision until the AAT makes a decision on the matter.

The AAT does not have the power to make orders awarding any compensation. An applicant would normally successfully seek compensation where, for example a tort has been committedâsuch as where the decision maker acted negligently or maliciously. But this must be established through the normal judicial process. The Australian Government Solicitor's office has confirmed that compensating successful applicants following an AAT appeal is not the current practice nor a desirable precedent given the extraordinary number of day-to-day administrative decisions are made and that may be potentially reviewed by the AAT. In addition, because the AAT has jurisdiction to review decisions on their merits, the AAT may arrive at a different decision to that of the original decision maker's, even where the latter's decision cannot be faulted at law. In such circumstances, it would be inappropriate to compensate an applicant where the original decision may be correct at law.

The Committee wrote to you suggesting that the four sets of Regulations are sufficiently important that it may be more appropriate to address the matters with which they deal through amendment of the enabling Act, when the changes would be subject to full parliamentary debate. The Committee advised you that one of its terms of reference is to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. Your reply dealt with this question briefly, advising that it would not be appropriate to amend the enabling Act because these are amendments of existing regulations.

With great respect, your advice lacks merit. For the purposes of the Committee's terms of reference it is irrelevant whether an instrument amends an existing instrument. The Committee's mandate to ensure that legislative instruments do not contain matter more appropriate for an Act is an important safeguard for parliamentary propriety and which the Committee is especially vigilant to enforce.

speech.para: When the Parliament relatively recently passed the Therapeutic Goods Act in 1991, it made provision for certain matters to be detailed in regulations. It is the Government's belief that the current amendments presently before the Senate, which prescribe requirements for the advertising of therapeutic goods, are necessary and convenient to give effect to the Act.

Section 63(2)(a) of the Therapeutic Goods Act provides for minor amendments through regulation in relation to committees and paragraph 63(2)(c) of the Act provides for the Governor General to make regulations for advertising of therapeutic goods.

While I acknowledge that there has been some controversy over the amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations, the majority of the controversy has resulted from misinformation about the effects of the amendments. In fact none of the proposed amendments affect consumers' access to therapeutic goods and they will not affect the status quo in relation to the advertising of these products. As the amendments were not intended to introduce significant change to current arrangements, the amendments were made to the regulations covering these activities.

para.inline: As you know, the subject matter of No 401 is contentious and is the subject of considerable public concern. The Committee has noted your further advice that you have established a committee of review to examine the issues contained in No 401. Its aim is to protect the rights of Parliament.

speech.para: I acknowledge the apparent complexity of the legislation and the uncertainty caused by the prohibition of the use of the term `drug free'.

The special Committee to consider the use of the term `drug free' is mandated to examine whether the use of the term drug free is appropriate when advertising certain medicinal products, and what alternatives might be used to accurately promote such products. I cannot preempt the deliberations of the Committee but I have asked the Committee to report to me by 8th May 1998. As you are aware, the findings of the Committee will be tabled in Parliament along with the Government's response to the recommendations.
The Committee has continued its work despite the disallowance of Statutory Rule 401 by a resolution of the Senate on 31 March 1998.

para.inline: You have advised that there is only one present AAT case that relates to the subject matter of No 401 and that the present Regulations should not affect the ability of the AAT to decide whether a notice should have been issued Here again the Committee assumes that if the matter is decided against the delegate of the Secretary then suitable financial compensation will be paid.

speech.para: I am advised that the advertiser in question has apparently continued to use the term `drug free' in advertisements despite (a) notification by the TGA in October 1996 that this was in breach of Thera peutic Goods Regulation No.7; and (b) losing the appeal against the initial decision.
In these circumstances it would appear difficult to quantify any loss of business.
Thank you again for your detailed comments and I trust that this letter has helped clarify a number of outstanding issues. Please contact me if you require any additional information.
Yours sincerely
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services

talk.start.para: âMy motion is similar to the last one but not as expansive. We thought we would tie them in together. If we have a division, I would advise people not to leave so they can come back in. I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1106 standing in my name for today relating to the order for production of documents be taken as a formal motion.
âIs there any objection to this being taken as a formal motion?
âYes, Madam President.
âPursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1106.

Briefly, there are two motions today for the discovery of certain documents. Mine is a much more specific motion. It only refers to focus group research undertaken by this government. The government has basically given, over time, four reasons for the non-production of documents: firstly, commercial-in-confidence; secondly, advice to government; thirdly, that there may be some threats to the security of individuals; and I would anticipate a fourth one that there are currently certain court proceedings in the Federal Court. May I say, Madam President, that none of those four objections could possibly apply to this far more restricted return to order.

Firstly, it is certainly not commercial-in-confidence to get focus group research. Secondly, it is not advice to government, otherwise this government would not have produced and forwarded to an estimates committee and to myself two sets of research in the last six monthsânamely, the focus group research into regional forest agreements and, secondly, focus group research into the testing of the Wik ads. On both occasions, the government, by way of requestâone by way of request of an estimates committee and one by way of request of freedom of informationâhas supplied that material.

The third ground, which generally and broadly covers the ACIL documents that Minister Alston has referred to on occasion, is that he is worried about the threat to security of people involved in these reports. No such prohibition applies simply to getting the results of focus group research. Finally, that focus group research has absolutely no relevance at the moment, and never will, to conspiracy proceedings in the Federal Court. I think there is an arguable case for the government to produce this focus group research, and to do it urgently.

It is made a little more poignant, however, when you look at to whom the focus group research was given. It was given to a company run by Mr Mark Textor. Mr Mark Textor of course is the Liberal Party pollster. I would like to know and I would like to be assured by the production of this material that he was not doing research that was useful to the Liberal Party. I suspect not. I suspect that, once these documents are handed over, if this motion is eventually carried and if we go through all of the proceedings and they actually hand over the focus group research, there is not going to be any dynamite in it. It will show, however, that the government used taxpayers' money and employed the Liberal Party pollster to let them know what the community attitudes were on the waterfront issues before they in fact launched their general strategy.

I can remember in government on many occasions the present government members demanding the production of opinion polling research. On many occasions it was handed over, on some it was not. Similarly, once we reverse our roles, we demand the opinion poll research. Sometimes it is handed over, sometimes it is not. But on this occasion I believe it should be because all the objections to the production of the rest of the ACIL documents are not relevant to the production of the specific documents.

They will show a government quite happy to spend $42,000 of taxpayers' money employing a Liberal Party pollsterâand, on occasions, I might add, a push pollsterâto do their research before they in fact developed a strategy on the waterfront. I would have liked to have included in my motion the report by Mr Jonathan Gaul, another member of the Liberal Party glitterati, who was also paid to provide a communications strategy, but I did not include it here because at least it possibly would have been barred to me under the question of advice to government.

So, in summary, I believe this motion is urgent. I believe it should be carried. I would hope that at some stage we might be able to cut to the chase and not go through another 25 minutes of debate and, if that is carried, another 25 or 30 minutes of precedence debate and then the substance of the motion, because I do not think any of that debate will change anyone's vote on this particular matter. I would hope that at some stage we might get an indication from people around the chamber so we can cut to the chase, have a vote and win or lose it.
