subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

Looking through this document, I see it is a report prepared by Justice Peter Gray and is his last report as Aboriginal Land Commissioner. I note in correspondence at the back of this report that the manner of His Honour's sending off from his work as a commissioner was not as gracious as it may have been. There was a difference between him and the government about the interpretation of a particular section of the relevant act. That is a pity because Justice Gray is a person of great legal abilityâhe is a great judgeâand of undoubted integrity. It is a pity that there was that hiccup, if you like, in his final days as Aboriginal Land Commissioner.

Mr Justice Gray was respected highly when he was a barrister at the Melbourne bar. I know he was highly respected as a judge. I commend him on the work he did in the Office of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner.

I note that this report was produced by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That body has not fared as well out of the budget as it might. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was established on the initiative of the Hon. Gerry Hand when he was minister for Aboriginal affairs.

The concept he had of ATSIC was that it should take the initiative as far as possibleâand consistent with the constitution and the sort of nation we areâin developing Aboriginal policy. This body is less than 10 years old. I would suggest that it still needs time to take on board all that needs to be taken on board to make it a near perfect body. To start to take certain powers away from it at this stage I think is poor policy. It is not the sort of policy that this body deserves to have applied to it. In any event, that is what has happened.

There are two concerns that this report raised. The first is that Mr Justice Gray was sent awayâI am not saying that his commission was in any way cut offâperhaps less graciously than he might have been. The second is that we must give the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission the full support that it deserves and the time it needs to mature into the sort of body it is going to become if it is not stymied in its efforts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

It would be a shame to see this document go through without being noted. It is an attractively set out document. It sets out the strategic direction for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. The headings in the documents are: `Goal 1: Documents', `Goal 2: Partnerships', and `Goal 3: People's Movement'. It also shows the members of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. It shows the strength of that body and the need for us as a parliament to take account of what it does. It is proper that we take account of this document. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO General Conference: Australian Delegation Report

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report sets out the results of the 29th meeting of UNESCO and Australia's participation in that conference. A common frame of reference before this particular conference was the issue of globaltyâthat is an interesting new word. In particular, the conference called attention to the hundreds of millions of humans who are being denied access to education.

I think it is particularly appropriate to focus on education tonight as students all over the country are participating in a candlelight vigil to protest against funding cuts. I would also like to draw to the attention of the Senate the weight of international agreement on the rights and responsibilities of education. The Director-General of UNESCO, Frederico Mayor, commenting on 50 years of education, stated:

The real and urgent threats to peace and international security are exclusion, poverty and underdevelopment and all the woes that accompany them. Yet, yesterday as today, education is among the best responsesâsometimes the only response that society has to offer: education for all, education for development, education for justice and liberty and peace.

I have spoken on many occasions about the government induced decline in the value of Australian education. Here I would like to set out the basic obligations that I believe Australia has as a member of the global family and the obligations we have undertaken for education locally and globally. Fifty years after UNESCO was established is an appropriate time to reflect on what has been achieved and restate the fundamental education right. This is particularly important after another budget which has not redressed the savage cuts we have seen to education across Australia.

In addition, the government has pursued us all with the need for change and flexibility. In some cases they have actually imposed change upon our community. In every situation education is the best means and preparation for dealing with unknown challenges. Unfortunately, this government has not maintained the same commitment to education, and that is education at all levels from primary, secondary and post secondary, right through to adult education and retraining.

Australia does have an accepted commitment to education as a signatory to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This declaration made education a right for everyone. By this declaration we recognise: firstly, that education shall be free, that at least in the elementary and fundamental stages, elementary education shall be compulsory, that technical and professional education shall be made generally available and that higher education should be equally accessible to all on the basis of merit; and, secondly, that education shall be directed to the full devel opment of the human personality and to the strengthening of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It shall promote understanding, tolerance and friendship among all nations, racial or religious groups, and shall further the activities of the United Nations for the maintenance of peace.
UNESCO was established to put these very rights into effect. In 1946 the constitution of UNESCO actually proclaimed:
The State Parties [believe] in full and equal opportunities for education for all.

Give fresh impulse to popular education and to the spread of culture . . . by instituting collaboration among the nations to advance the ideal of equality of educational opportunities without regard to race, sex or any distinctions, economic or social.

These are visionary statements and they are worthy of fulfilment. There is a range of international agreements that have reasserted the basic rights to education. They include among manyâand I have at least nine, but I do not think I can speak fast enough to include themâdeclarations such as the Declaration of the Right of the Child adopted by the General Assembly in November 1959, which actually states:
The child is entitled to receive education, which shall be free and compulsory.

There are a number of other international covenants and conventions on the rights of various groups, including children, but I will not read them out. There is a significant array of international consensus on the issue of education.

The message to the government, any government, is clear: education is and should be a top priority. It should not be massively cut in the way that we have seen in recent budgets, including massive cuts to university operating grants, cuts which total around six per cent over four years. If we factor in NTU wage claims, those cuts are much more excessive than that, and a number of cuts have seen a sharp decline in education in this country. Cuts to student assistance, like Austudy and Abstudy, have made it more difficult for many people to undertake or to continue study.

The irony is that many of these cuts need not have taken place, as we have seen in the last 24 hours. The budget surplus is indeed plentiful and we are looking at something like $3 billion worth of cuts which should never have been made, and many groups should not have been affected as adversely and as negatively as they have been, including the education sector. I seek leave to continue my remarks later, as I could speak on this issue for a longer period of time. But I do wish to commend to honourable senators the UNESCO report; it is one worth reading.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

It is an important day for issues of peace and disarmament, as I mentioned earlier. We have been asked today to respond to the multilateral treaty, the comprehensive test ban treaty, signed in September 1996. I was reminded of the fact that it is very relevant to what has happened in the last few days or what has been reported to have happened in the last few days in relation to underground testing from India. Nobody will put their hand up and say that what India has undertaken is acceptable in this day and age.

I am very concerned, however, at the role Australia may have taken in what has happened over the last few days. The role goes back to the situation at that time in 1996 when Australia was involved in various negotiations on peace and disarmament, including not just the comprehensive test ban treaty but the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. I looked back to question 190 that I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill, on 31 October 1996. Part of that question states:
Does the current CTBT text contain an entry into force provision that requires all 44 named countries, including India, Pakistan and Israel, to sign the treaty before it enters into force . . .
The answer states:

The CTBT adopted by the United Nations General Assembly and opened for signature on 24 September 1996 will enter into force 180 days after the date of deposit of the instruments of ratification by all 44 states listed in the treaty, including the five nuclear weapon states and India, Pakistan and Israel, but in no case earlier than two years after the treaty's opening for signature.
I also asked:
. . . has India refused to sign the treaty due to the lack of a timetable for disarmament or timetable for negotiations for disarmament.

What was referred to there was the timetable for those nuclear weapon states, those that consider themselves different from anywhere else that they can insist the rest of the world not develop nuclear weapons or not move toward the development of nuclear weapons but are quite happy to get heavy handed with other countries, including Iraq, if they feel it is right for them to do so and are also quite happy to hold on to their own arsenal and weapons of mass destruction.

In this particular caseâdid India refuse to sign due to that lack of a timetable for disarmament?âthe answer was yes. If we have a situation where 44 named countries have to sign before the treaty becomes operative, that means that we have a comprehensive test ban treaty which cannot become operative until those other countries like the United States, Britain and France agree to actually move towards their own disarmament and not sit in their own nuclear towers and insist that everyone else in the world move towards weapons of mass destruction.

The role that Australia played, I believe, was to play the game of the major weapons powers, to talk countries from the non-aligned countries, including Indonesia, into signing the nuclear non-proliferation treaty even though it meant the comprehensive test ban treaty therefore was in danger of becoming inoperative, and that is exactly what we see. We can today say that India never signed the comprehensive test ban treaty. That is true. I am not saying that what they did was right; it is not and it was not. However, it could have been foreseen.

I believe Australia played a role that we cannot afford to be proud of. I think we have to move in the future not only towards having Canberra conventions but also towards trying to make sure that those nuclear weapon states in the world really do move towards getting rid of their own weapons of mass destruction so that we can start putting pressure on the peripheral states and the threshold states to do the same.

talk.start.para: âI would like to add some remarks to those already spoken by Senator Margetts. The issue of nuclear weapons is obviously a very difficult one. Indeed, Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds, as you would know, in the past it has been a very emotional issue indeed. It still is, although perhaps not as emotional as it once was. Clearly, the fewer weapons that there are in the world, whether nuclear or otherwise, the better it is. We have found with our own gun policy in Australia that the fewer guns there are the better it is. War is a very destructive exercise no matter how it is conducted. I see that Senator McGauran is in the chamber. He has recently seen places where there has been war, not with nuclear weapons but with more conventional ones. He would bear out that that leaves a most destructive legacy.

speech.para: There is criticism to be made, as Senator Margetts has said. I think it was Harold Macmillan who once said that it was better to jaw-jaw than war-war. That was a long time ago, probably before Senator Forshaw was conscious of what was going on in the world, and before you were too, Madam Acting Deputy President. Unfortunately, in terms of age, I can remember it quite clearly. Be that as it may, a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty is a good thing. With all its faults, it is a good thing. The more the world talksâwe talk about a global village and about a globalisation of the economy, and all of that is trueâabout banning weapons and the more we talk about banning war the more likely it is that we will avoid it.

A lot of the heat has gone out of the world since the end of the Cold War, although what has been substituted for that has been a lot more battles amongst nations on the basis of nationality than there used to be. It would be a terrible thing if that sort of war was fought in any way by nuclear weapons. Although the emotion that used to be there has modified a bit because we do not have the two super powersâwe only have oneâthe issue of nuclear weapons is still a very great issue given the fact that nations are still fighting each other.

India has been criticised, and justifiably so. They have said, `As soon as we've tested these weapons, we're happy to sign a treaty and then of course we'll never use them,' but Pakistan and other countries get worried about that. It is important that we have a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, as was done in New York on 10 December 1996. It is not going to bring perfection and it is not going to bring that peace we want, but it is better to have the process than not.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âOrder! There being no further consideration of government documents, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight on a topic which is of longstanding interest to me, and that is the area of information technology. Tonight I intend to continue a series of speeches on a theme that I started in the last session. We are indeed at the start of the information revolution, a revolution as important to change in the economy and in society as the Industrial Revolution was 170 years ago. One of the large emerging factors in this revolution that is coming about at a breathtaking pace at the moment is the whole world of e-commerce.

speech.para: E-commerce, or electronic commerce, is the selling of goods and services over the Internet. World wide this is expected to boom from $6 billion, which is the most recent figure in the international economy, to more than $300 billion in the year 2002. What is driving this electronic commerce is the incredibly rapid development of the Internet which, in terms of e-commerce usage, is doubling every 100 days world wide. People on the Internet who will have access to this electronic commerce are expected to increase by tenfoldâthat is, from 100 million people to one billion peopleâby 2005. That is roughly 20 per cent of the world's population.

The rate of the expansion of this new technology and the commerce that it will drive is phenomenal. Just four years ago e-commerce usage of the Internet in the United States was being debated as they tried to work out what sorts of protocols and procedures could be used to trade in goods and services over the Internet. At that time the whole thing was a relatively new concept. How things have changed in just a very short time. Australia is really trying to catch up with this very rapidly developing global phenomenon.

Recently in Canberra was the E-commerce Summit, organised by Minister Alston's Office of the Information Economy. It was held here several weeks ago in Parliament House and it drew a very impressive group of people from business, government and consumer groups, industrial leaders and people concerned with the regulation of industry. The summit was a very important step to get Australian business ready for e-commerce, ready to compete in this new information economy. Australia cannot afford, given its rapid development, to take a wait and see approach. We need to be gearing up very rapidly for this new economic revolution that is now flowing over the whole world.

We can look to the US for the very broad effect of the information revolution, and it already points the way to Australia's economic future. In the US, the Internet accounts for one-third of real growth in their economy. Information technology industries have grown from four per cent to eight per cent of the US economy in the last decade. It has created seven million jobs in information technology and related industry.

The interesting thing is that it is creating high wage jobs. The average wage, for example, in the United States is $28,000. In the information technology industry, the average wage is $44,000. So there is some very good news in the type of economy that is developing at this time. Some 45 per cent of business investment in the United States at the moment is in information technology, and it is up from three per cent just 15 years ago. The US believes the importance of this will tend to accelerate.

At the E-commerce Summit, we had Mr Ira Magaziner, who is the special adviser to President Clinton on e-commerce. He had some very interesting things to tell us about the way in which this is developing in the United States currently. It is believed that business to business electronic commerce will grow from $6 billion per annum to $300 billion per annum by the year 2002. Retailing is one of the big areas that will be subject to rapid change in the immediate future.

Already sales of things like books, clothing and real estate are gaining very rapid acceptance in this e-commerce world, but there will be a rapidly expanding range of products and services developed and delivered digitally from this point on. Things like software, music, movies, video games, insurance policies, banking, consulting services, education, medical diagnostic services and news services are just some of the things that will be transported digitally in this new world of electronic commerce. Significantly, Ira Magaziner said that he believed that this will drive world economic growth for the next 25 years. If he is right, the e-commerce revolution will create the largest and longest boom in world economic history.

Magaziner said that the United States had five principles it used when setting its policy in examining the information economy. These are principles which Australians should consider very carefully and should be debating very vigorously at this point in time. Some of these principles, if put into place, would certainly have some very big upsides economically, but socially, for some of the groups in our economy, there could be some fairly significant downsides. We are moving into a totally new world, and we are moving into it very rapidly. So this debate, in terms of these principles, should occur right now.

I want to outline the five principles that he said were driving Internet policy in the United States. The first principle is that the private sector should lead Internet growth. They have found that government structures in this new world where change is so rapid often get in the way and do not have the flexibility to respond to the changes that are needed to let this e-commerce sector grow at a pace at which it is capable of growing.

The second principle is that the whole area should be market driven. It should not be a regulated area. Regulation is hard obviously not only because of its international dimensions but also because of the convergence of the technologies involved in e-commerce and the way in which our structures currently tend to segment different markets which in the e-commerce world will all merge into one. Other things in the technology area are changing as well. Where there were certain limits, particularly created by bandwidth on the Internet, new technology means that all these barriers will come down as well. His claim is that government, in its regulations, can get in the way.

The third principle is that any government intervention that does exist should be minimal. The fourth principle is the need to take heed of the medium that we are dealing with. We are not dealing just with big businesses often in this e-commerce world. We are dealing with a whole range of smaller organisations in a very decentralised structure. So, to have this whole market work properly, you need as much flexibility to allow smaller players in a wide range of sites to be able to develop their businesses with as little hindrance as possible.

His final principle relating to e-commerce was related to its global nature and the need to remove, particularly between countries, not only tariff but also non-tariff trade barriers. He sees that the Internet and its trade should be free of any customs dutiesâand he advocates world trade organisations making electronic transmissions free of customs dutyâthat any taxation should be tax neutral and that no discriminatory tax should be placed against the Internet.

What I have outlined to date indicates a number of things about e-commerce which should raise questions in people's minds. Seeing I am nearly out of time, I will continue the discussion of those principles tomorrow. These are things that should not necessarily be just accepted. In this new information age, we need to respond in an appropriate way. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThey came like thieves in the night. They came with balaclavas to hide their faces. They came with weapons and they came with vicious dogs. This is a scene that has been repeated in history many, many times. Fortunately, our country has never had to witness it, until recently. It is the sort of thing that happened in Europe during the 1940s. It is the sort of thing that happened in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s in Eastern Europe. It is what happened in 1956 in Hungary. It is what happened in 1968 in Czechoslovakia. It is what happened in Argentina and Chile. It is what happened in China. It is the symbol of oppression of people's rights and, sadly, just prior to Easter, it happened here on the ports around Australia.

speech.para: The symbolism is ironic. Guard dogs, men in balaclavas, weapons in the middle of the night. And it happened right on the eve of Easter, the time when most democratic nations in the world celebrate one of the most significant events in the history of Christianity, the death and resurrection of Christ. On this occasion, the irony is quite significant because what we had was the employer, Patrick, on the eve of the Easter holidays and with the full support and connivance of the John Howard government, engaging in an illegal and deceitful action to destroy a trade union.

talk.start.para: âMake your biblical comparisons.

âI have referred to history. I have referred to the importance of trade unions in history and I will refer to the importance of religious organisations in history, because what Senator McGauran refuses to accept and understand is that, in all democratic societies throughout history, it is often the trade union movement and the organised churches that are first attacked whenever despots or tyrants take over. Why are they attacked? They are attacked because they represent the fundamental right of human beings to assemble peacefully in collective organisations, such as trade unions, or to follow their religious beliefs in recognised free churches and religious organisations. If the symbolism and the comparisons with the anti-democratic regimes of other parts of the world, particularly Europe, are something that Senator McGauran does not want to hear about, then certainly it demonstrates how sensitive he is on this issue.

speech.para: The liberalisation of Eastern EuropeâI will explain this for Senator McGauran's benefit, but I am sure he knows thisâactually began with the struggle of a trade union movement, Solidarity, to establish itself in Poland as a legitimate organisation. Similarly, the apartheid regime of South Africaâwhich was supported by many people who preceded people from Senator McGauran's party and this governmentâwas defeated because of organisations like COSATU, the trade union movement in that country that struggled so long against oppression.

Similarly, we still have these struggles going on todayâin Indonesia, for instance. It was not so long ago that even in the greatest democracy in the worldâthe United Statesâthe farm workers had to struggle to survive. I can recall in my early days in the trade union movement in this country in the 1970s reading about and then subsequently visiting America to meet Cesar Chavez. Cesar Chavez started an organisation for the US farm workers, which the conservative government in California at that time and the major employers in the farming industryâparticularly the fruit industryâset out to destroy. Trade union officials were murdered because they stood up for the right of an organisation to exist and enrol workers.

The situation is this. What we have here is nowhere near the excesses that occurred then, and I accept that. But, unfortunately, what we have here is a government that is so hell-bent on destroying a trade union that it is prepared to support the sending in, as I said, of men in balaclavas in the middle of the night with guard dogs in order to sack workers. Many workers were sacked that night. In total, 2,000 workers working on the waterfront were dismissed.

Members of the government have claimed that they are not setting out to destroy a trade union, but listen to the rhetoric. Go back and study the words they have used. In the months leading up to this event, we had Peter Reith continuously standing up in the parliament and everywhere else labelling every person who worked on the waterfront as a greedy thug, as a greedy, lazy bludger. They were the words that Peter Reith used time and time and time again to talk about decent Australian people. No proof. No evidence. He just categorised them all as greedy, lazy bludgers, turned them into scapegoats and tried to turn the rest of the Australian community against them. He tried to blame them for all of the economic ills of this country. That is what they have said, and they have continued to do it. They tried to make out by distorting the figures that they all earned $90,000 a year and did little or no work.

I happen to know a person who worked on the waterfront. I know a few, but I know one in particular who is a neighbour of mine. I will not name him because I do not particularly want to get into those sorts of personal details, but I know this about him. Firstly, he is a hardworking, decent Australian. Secondly, he has worked on the waterfront for 18 years. Thirdly, he has got a wife and three children. And, fourthly, he is not even a member of the wharfies' union. He was a supervisor working on the wharves. He was a member of the supervisors union, not the MUA. They were not on strike. They had an enterprise agreement with Patricks. He was sacked. He was telephoned at home and told he did not have a job anymore.

There were 600 workers other than those in the MUA who were sacked. They were innocent of any crime. They were innocent of any illegal or legal industrial activity. They were busy doing their jobs on the waterfront and they were sacked. What was John Howard's response when this was put to him? John Howard said on TVâand these are his exact wordsâ`Well, they're all in the MUA and innocent people get affected.' That is true: innocent people get affected, particularly in events like wars or other catastrophes. But innocent people get affected when tyrannical governments ignore the fundamental rights of their citizens as this government has done. In its ideological obsession to set out to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia, it has ignored the fundamental rights of those people, and hundreds upon hundreds of innocent people and their families have been affected.

John Howard and Peter Reith should wake up, understand their obligation to the Australian community and set about negotiating the issue of waterfront reform in a democratic way, and not have to rely upon the methods of despots and tyrants.

talk.start.para: âI acknowledge Senator Forshaw's comments when he talked about some of the great events of this century being brought about by the union movement. I referred earlier to education and should acknowledge tonight the National Union of Students. Members of the student union are in the gallery this evening and hopefully are bringing about similar progressive change in education in this countryâbut with this government, I never know.

speech.para: I wish tonight to address an education issue of grave importance. Last year, some senators in this place may recall the issue of HECS places being sacrificed to introduce places for domestic up-front fee paying places. This issue actually arose when minutesâ

talk.start.para: âWhat about P&O?
âNo, P&O were not involved in this crisis, Senator McGauran.
âHey, Forshaw, what about P&O?
âOrder! Senator McGauran, you have been persistently interjecting and I think I have been more than tolerant, but I will not continue to be tolerant if you continue to interject.

âI am talking about the issue of HECS places being replaced by those for full fee paying domestic students. Minutes from the University of Sydney's Faculty of Veterinary Science board meeting of 5 March were presented to an estimates committee. These minutes detailed the faculty's plans to drop its first year HECS intake to 67 places from a planned 83. The minutes stated:

speech.para: From 1997 the quota for Year 1 HECS-paying students has been changed to 65 in order to accommodate a mixture of 25 prospective International and Australian Fee-paying students from 1998.
That statement appears on page 3 of the minutes. The statement demonstrates blatant disregard of the government's claim that fee paying students would not displace HECS places.

When this was brought to the attention of the former Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, we received a rather feeble response. I quote from a response to a question on notice to the estimates committee:

The Vice-Chancellor of the University of Sydney has advised that the University has reduced its first year intake for Veterinary Science in 1997 from 83 to 67 students because of concerns over the high drop out rate in the course.

The minister was happy with this explanation that was given and, at least to my knowledge, has accepted the lower HECS load. From my inquiries, I gather that the current first year is comprised of 69 HECS and 19 domestic up-front fee paying students. The minutes stated that the faculty was planning for a mixture of 25 international and domestic fee paying students this year but, given previous enrolment trends, I find it hard to believe that the international student intake would be as low as six. However, we have been unable to find out just how many international students are enrolled at the University of Sydney to substantiate, or otherwise, those comments. In light of this, I find the response from the university and the seeming lack of interest by the minister and the department in this matter of great concern.

That concern has been compounded now by a letter that I received, as has the current Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), from Ms Avril Baird. Over the last nine years, Ms Baird has strived to fulfil her desire to work with animals through a number of academic pursuits as well as through her work with the development of animal courses in the TAFE sector involving collaborative programming and work with a veterinary teaching hospital. Her academic record is a Bachelor of Science in Agriculture and a Master's research degree from the Faculty of Veterinary Science (Sydney).

Despite her completion of the Master's in the same area at the same institution, Avril's application to gain a HECS placement in the undergraduate veterinary science course this year was not successful. This, in itself, is unusual enough to warrant further attention from the minister. But her story gets even more interesting.

When the first round placements were announced, Avril Baird made an appointment with the Dean of the Faculty, Professor David Fraser, to discuss the possibility of her receiving a second round offer. After this meeting, it was agreed by the professor that they would investigate the possibility, but apparently no definite undertaking was given that her application would be successful.

A few days later, on 3 February, apparently while picking up her dog from the University of Sydney veterinary hospital, Ms Baird was approached by Dr William Porges, the Associate Dean, Professional and Community Relations, at this same faculty. Until this time, Dr Porges had never initiated a conversation with Ms Baird. To her knowledge, he was not aware that she had applied to gain a placement in the undergraduate veterinary science course. Dr Porges indicated that she would receive a letter shortly, and in fact indicated his surprise that she had not already been contacted. After this conversation, Avril Baird believed that her application had been accepted and that at last, as she said in her letter to me, `My life's ambition was going to be fulfilled.'

That Friday, 6 February, the newspapers did not have Ms Baird's name in the second round of offers and she was understandably quite devastated. She rang the university application centre who confirmed that she had not received an offer. Her application was refused. Avril Baird has since approached the student ombudsman and has appealed against the decision, but was informed by Ros Pesman, chair of the academic board, that:

Because there are only some 20 to 30 HECS places available for category B students each year and some two to three hundred applicants, competition for the places is very very strong with the result that many students with outstanding records and very high motivation fail to gain a place. Your ranking was not sufficiently high for you to qualify for one of the Category B places.

Ms Baird wrote to the vice-chancellor seeking clarification as to the events which had occurred. She wanted to be told why she had not got a place, why she could finish a Masters of Veterinary Science in that faculty and yet not be accepted into the undergraduate degree. The Vice-Chancellor, Professor Gavin Brown, wrote back to Miss Baird after seeking advice from the Dean, Professor Fraser. In his response dated 27 March, the vice-chancellor stated the `objective criteria' for applicants with a tertiary record may be `supplemented by the more subjective criteria of a demonstrated commitment to veterinary science where relevant information is supplied.'

The vice-chancellor stated that Dr Porges was one of the staff that the dean had contacted who `erroneously concluded that this inquiry indicated that your application had been successful'. The vice-chancellor apologised for this `simple but unfortunate misunderstanding' and reaffirmed the decision of the faculty.

I share the concerns of Miss Baird regarding the responses of both the academic board and the vice-chancellor. First, there is some question as to whether or not the `objective criteria' has been fully investigated. This is stated by the vice-chancellor and also by the academic board who found that her `ranking was not sufficiently high.'

My understanding is that Miss Baird submitted her thesis for her masters research degree to the University of Sydney on 20 August 1997. This had not apparently been accounted for in her assessment as a candidate for the bachelor's degree. Secondly, and still on the objective criteria, Miss Baird's ranking has been based on her grade point average of a lesser degree, that is, her Bachelor of Agricultural Science has been used to arrive at that objective criteria ranking. This grade point average of 4.45 out of a possible seven gives Miss Baird a rank of 81. It will probably give Miss Baird no comfort to learn that another student did enter the Bachelor of Veterinary Science who was also assessed on a bachelor degree with a grade point average of 3.94 out of the possible seven or a ranking of 74âthat student made it in.

It would appear that, contrary to the claim of the academic board, Avril's ranking was sufficiently high. The only real defence left that the university could put up would be what Vice-Chancellor Professor Brown termed `subjective criteria', that is, as he stated, her application `may be supplemented by the more subjective criteria of a demonstrated commitment to veterinary science where relevant information is supplied'. Clearly, from her nine years working towards not only entrance in the degree but working in this field, through her work with TAFE, et cetera, Miss Baird has demonstrated this commitment.

What is of concern here is that the vice-chancellor indicates that the confusion has arisen because Dr Porges was one of several staff members that the Dean, Professor Fraser, consulted to investigate Miss Baird's subjective criteria. Miss Baird included in her application several referees who were both staff members of the faculty and who had worked closely with her. The dean did not approach these people.

As indicated by the uniqueness of Dr Porges actually initiating a conversation with Miss Baird, he has little to do with her professionally or academically and was definitely not used as a referee by Miss Baird. So why then has this process been followed? Why has the application of Miss Baird not been given proper consideration, why has she not been given the benefit of having the information she supplied to back up her application being taken into consideration?

I believe the crux of this issue is that this faculty is being pushed into pursuit of up-front fee payers at all costs and therefore due process has not been followed when deciding course offers. Perhaps another up-front fee payer came into contention and knocked Ms Baird out of the running. We will probably never know, but I believe that the minister should do his utmost to get to the bottom of this murky issue.

I have a number of comments to follow. I have spoken to the opposition and to the representative of the government on duty to ask whether I may seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks which go on to reveal the real intrigue. I request the government to act on this issue. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks.
Leave granted.
The remarks read as followsâ
While the Minister is investigating Miss Baird's situation, he might want to take note of other disturbing events taking place in this Faculty and around the country where fee paying is concerned.
Allegations of preferential treatment for fee-paying students at this university, and in this faculty, are not new.
Some of the most recent were broadcast on ABC radio National some weeks ago.

Dr. Paul Hopwood, lecturer at the University of Sydney in Veterinary Anatomy has claimed that he has substantial evidence, which supports the theory that the University of Sydney is giving fee-paying students an unfair advantage over HECS students.
In August of 1997, Dr Paul Hopwood noticed a new overseas feepaying student in his first year class, who had been admitted to the course more than half way through the academic year.

He stated `In 25 years within this faculty, it, to the best of my knowledge, has never happened before. It's a little strange that a course that has already had part of the work examined, for a course that requires attendance at a large number of dissection classes, for a student to be enrolled half-way through that course, is more than enough to make you raise your eyebrows'.

When asked by Radio national's Tom Morton, what the problem with a student beginning a course half-way through the academic year was, he replied `Well, the problem would be that half of the teaching material has already been presented and because the teaching material is based on animal dissection work, it's very difficult for a student to be able to cover the material.'
The University of Sydney's rules state that a student must attend 90% of lectures in order to pass a subject, unless they can show due cause why they should be exempted.
Dr. Paul Hopwood believes that this student was given special treatment, his response to this was, and I quote,

`I think this is obvious: not only does such a late enrolment advantage a student, I mean they don't have to find accommodation or other costs that the other students completing a full year have to go through, but this student would not be capable of completing the work without special tuition, and the University provided, to my direct knowledge, the services of two tutors at University expense. Whereas Australian HECS students don't receive these benefits.'
After further examination of the overseas student's academic transcript, he discovered that the student had absolutely no training which might have been relevant to the course he was teaching.

He said, `The course was being taught based on the dissection of the dog. As you would appreciate, veterinary practitioners routinely operate on cats and dogs, it's a substantial part of their training, and this student had no anatomical training on dog.'

This was met by the following claims made by the Dean of Veterinary Science, who believed that the student in question deserved to be given credit for the work she'd already done at university overseas, and I quote;

`The student had had experience in anatomy, human anatomy and human dissection so that that was one of the reasons for making this decision. And of course veterinary anatomy is simply comparative anatomy; the human anatomy is one species and the whole purpose of veterinary anatomy is to compare different species, and that was a very good grounding for the veterinary anatomy which was subsequently done'.
In response, the lecturer Dr. Paul Hopwood is not satisfied with this X explanation.
He is quoted as saying `Well unless you believe that veterinary surgeons should be operating on people, and human surgeons should be operating on dogs and cats I find that view rather amazing.'

I guess the lure of as much as $26,000 + per year that an institution can gain from an international fee-paying student must be great in the face of the devastation that the Coalition's budget cuts to university operating grants of 6% over five years have created.
These allegations made by Dr Hopwood, and the letter I received from Avril Baird must be responded to by the Minister as a matter of urgency.
I find it disturbing that the penalty for breaching the 25% limit on domestic upfront fee places is $9,000. A figure far less than the potential profits of these places.

However, the most disturbing factor of all has been the disinterest with which successive Government Minister's and University's such as the University of Sydney (and they are not alone in reduced their HECS load to increase the likelihood of fee-paying places) have treated apparent breaches of the edict not to sacrifice HECS places.
The motto for Sydney Uni translates to `Same mind under a different sky' but the post Howard version might read `same mind under different rules'.

talk.start.para: âI would like to preface my speech tonight by extending my congratulations to my colleague and friend the Treasurer, Peter Costello, on a far sighted and responsible 1998-99 budget. I would like to acknowledge the thinking behind the budget, the commitment to the Australian people which underlies the budget strategy and the determination to share the burdens and the rewards which will give, as the Treasurer said, young people, home buyers, small business and job seekers better opportunities and a bright future. It will allow us to care for our older people and give hope to the younger ones.

speech.para: This evening I wish to return to the main theme of my maiden speech: the reliance of many Australians on welfare and the growth of the welfare culture in our country. Just 20 years ago in 1978, spending on welfare in Australia was about 27 per cent of the national budget. That percentage has now risen to nearly 39 per centâa massive increase in 20 years. This escalation clearly cannot continue. It is imperative that it is reigned in not only because of hard economic realities, but also because of the massive social cost of welfare in our community.

The values which underpin Australia's culture are being attacked by the welfare mentality. No longer do some people have the same cocky self-confidence which has characterised this nation for so long. Instead, they look desperately to government to solve their problems, to hold their hands and to pay their bills. Last financial year, an additional 130,000 people became dependent on government payments. One in five Australians over 20 is now dependent on welfare, and that does not include those in receipt of an age pension. Forty-three per cent of all Australian children now live in a family that relies on welfareâa jump of more than 10 per cent in the last five years and something, surely, that no political party can condone or support.

I believe that the best thing you can do for someone on welfare is to help get them off welfare. The whole purpose of the social welfare system was supposed to be a safety net to prevent people falling into poverty and despair. Instead, for many, it has become a sticky web trapping people in poverty and despair. The culture of dependency eats at your confidence, bites into your being, poisons all hope. This is a downward spiral. Formerly self-reliant people fall into a poverty trap as the social welfare system and the taxation system conspire to make it impossible to get out. It is often better to stay on welfare or on a very low income supplemented by welfare, than it is to try to work your way out of it and become self-supporting again. This is simply not good enough. What messages are we giving our children, what ethics will they learn, what values will they believe in?

Our children will learn that in some families it is financially better not to work, and so they will not. A recent study has found that a family with one child and a single income of $20,000 had more disposable income than a similar family earning $30,000. Welfare boosted the first families' $20,000 to $28,427. The family earning $30,000 received fewer benefits and ended up with $26,697ânearly $2,000 less than the lower income family. The extra $10,000 per year in salary translated to a net loss of $40 a week, or an effective tax rate of $240 on earnings of $200âa marginal tax rate of 120 per cent.
This problem is recognised by the government, if not the opposition. As the Treasurer said last night, with some understatement, I believe:
The interaction of the tax and social security systems reduces the incentive to find work or to earn more.
As the head of the Audit Commission, Professor Bob Officer observed:
It becomes the culture to rely on the government. Welfare encourages dependency and often leads to false claims.'

Look at the results of the Minister for Social Security's recent crackdown on social security fraud and compliance: 1,319 convictions for welfare fraudâan increase of almost 20 per cent over the same period last year.

Since July 1996, some $600 million, or nearly $1.1 million per day, has been recovered for the taxpayers. In addition, nearly 200,000 people had payments cancelled or reduced in the first six months of the financial yearâa massive increase of 25.4 per cent over the same period in the previous year. Claiming unemployment benefits whilst in jail, on holidays overseas, or whilst actually working on the snowfields is a well-documented phenomenon. Nearly $120 millionâalmost half of all debt recovery from reviewsâcame from the allegedly unemployed. Ripping off the government, which is what a lot of these people think they are doing, is supposedly okay. The reality is that it is not the government that they are ripping off. It is their neighbours, their friends and their family.

We all need to acknowledge the mutual obligationâthe give and takeâinherent in society and in the social security system. We need to combine fairness and compassion for the genuinely needy with the imperative to help people off the culture of dependency and into an environment of self-reliance; and this government is putting in place the mechanisms to assist with this very necessary attitudinal change.

We have introduced work for the doleâthe quintessential example of mutual obligation in actionâand other programs to help young people improve their job prospects. The budget is full of examples to assist those in genuine need. We can only afford the fair and effective social security system that we need if we have a healthy economy and this governmentâas our actions and this week's budget are showingâis achieving that.

Look at employment. What this government has delivered on employment is fantastic. Even with 35,000 extra people joining the labour market last month, unemployment in this country has fallen to 7.9 per cent.

talk.start.para: âYou sacked 12,000 locally in Canberraâoh sorry, I forgot, add another 2,000 or 3,000 to that. That is what we are dealing withâyou cause unemployment.
âIt is all right for you to interject, Kate Lundy, but under your government unemployment reached 11.3 per centâover 1 million unemployed.

speech.para: We now have, at 7.9 per cent, the lowest unemployment rate since October 1990. Under this government, last month a total of 58,200 jobs were createdâ42,500 of them were full-time but you don't want to hear the good news, do you, Senator Lundy.

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Lundy has been interjecting continually since the start of Senator Synon's remarks, and I ask that you call her to order.
âI have been aware of Senator Lundy's interjection, but she hasn't been able to be heard and that is why I have not called her to order. But I wouldâ
âI have been hearing her, Madam Acting Deputy President.

âI spoke very severely to Senator McGauran for continuous interjection because his voice was very penetrating and was disrupting the flow of the speech. I did not feel that was so in your case, Senator Synon, but I will ask Senator Lundy to cease interjecting. Please continue.

âThank you. A radical review of the links between the social welfare system and the taxation system must be a priority for this country. The government has demonstrated that the taxation system is broken, and I would like to congratulate the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for having the determination to confront this serious problem in the taxation system and for the development of a comprehensive plan for reform. Our plan will remove many of the incentives to stay on welfare built into the current taxation system.

speech.para: In closing, I would like to emphasise that the coalition believes in helping to get people off welfare. The ALP believes in keeping people dependent on welfare. We want all Australians to beâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 30 January 1998:

question.para: (1) With reference to the application of the phrase `or his services having been otherwise terminated' (section 7(1) Superannuation Act 1976) to cessation of employment on health grounds of members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme: Can some actual examples be provided of the words which were used, and the sources of those words, to describe the manner in which the employment had been terminated (for example `ceased employment on invalidity grounds').

(2) If an employer, which is in possession of an Australian Government Medical Officer's report and recommendation which indicates an employee is not fit to perform his or her duties, refuses to retire the employee but alternatively processes a resignation, does the Commissioner for Superan nuation `have a discretion' between paying a 66(1) benefit and a section 80 (resignation) benefit.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Subsection 7(1) of the Superannuation Act 1976 provides:

"7(1) A reference in this Act to the retirement of an eligible employee on the ground of invalidity shall be read as a reference to his or her having been retired or his or her services having been otherwise terminated, on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform his or her duties."
Subsection 7(1) may be broken down as follows:
"A reference in this Act to the retirement of an eligible employee on the ground of invalidity shall be read as a reference to:

(i) an eligible employee having been retired on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform his duties, or (ii) an eligible employee's services having been otherwise terminated on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform his duties."

The reason for there being two limbs in sub-s 7(1) is to ensure that the various forms of employment by which a person becomes an `eligible employee' within the meaning of sub-s.3(1) are brought within the ambit of sub-s 7(1). Sub-s 7(1) recognises that some sorts of eligible employees are retired whereas other sorts of eligible employees cannot properly be said to be retired but rather, have their services terminated.
Specific examples of `eligible employees' who may have their services "otherwise terminated on the ground of physical or mental incapacity to perform his or her duties" are:
. High Court of Australia Act 1979

"24.(1) The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the Chief Executive and Principal Registrar by reason of the misbehaviour or the physical or mental incapacity of the Chief Executive and Principal Registrar."
. Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983
"18.(1) The Governor-General may remove a non-executive Director from office for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity."

(2) Retirement on the ground of invalidity is provided for in Part IVA of the Superannuation Act 1976. Section 54C provides that an eligible employee cannot be retired on the ground of invalidity without the approval of the CSS Board. The Commissioner for Superannuation no longer has any power with regard to invalidity retirement. Part IVA sets out the process that the CSS Board must follow in deciding whether to approve a retirement.

Subsection 7(2) provides the CSS Board with a discretion to deem that the person be retired on the ground of invalidity where the person has ceased to be an eligible employee before attaining his or her maximum retiring age by reason of having been retired or his or her services having been otherwise terminated other than on the grounds of invalidity.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, on notice, on 9 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Have any company injunctions been taken out under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 or the Trade Practices Act 1974 against protests and boycott actions by consumers, environmentalists or human rights activists whether individuals groups or body corporate; if so, can details be provided including a comparison of the number with action taken in previous years under the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

(2) Has the Minister received any complaint since the promulgation of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the new sections 45D, 45DA and 45DB of the Trade Practices Act 1974, that the new Act has stifled environmental, human rights, spiritual, cultural, or consumer protest in any way; if so, can details be provided.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Schedule 17 of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendments Act 1996 (WROLA) introduced amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA). Sections 45D, 45DA, 45DB, 45DC 45DD and 45DE, 45EA and 45EB were incorporated into the TPA and commenced on 17 January 1997 (the new boycott provisions). Relevant provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the IR Act) were repealed.

Prior to the amendments made by WROLA, the provisions relating to boycott conduct in the industrial context were contained in Division 7 of Part VI of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the IR Act). These provisions were inserted in the IR Act by the Industrial Relations Reform Act (IRR Act), which also repealed section 45E and amended section 45D of the TPA to exclude "boycott conduct" within the meaning of Division 7 of Part VI of the IR Act from its scope

While my department does not have direct responsibility for administering the provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974, it has an informal role in monitoring actions taken under the boycott provisions. My department has no record of any instance where an injunction has been granted under the new boycott provisions of the TPA in instances involving protests and boycott actions by consumers, environmentalists or human rights activists whether individuals, groups or bodies corporate.

The Assistant Treasurer has indicated that neither the Department of Treasury nor the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is aware of injunctions granted under the new boycott provisions of the TPA against any individual, group or body corporate in relation to protest or boycott action by consumer, environmentalist or human rights activists.

In relation to the former Division 7, Part VI of the IR Act (i.e., as amended by the IRR Act), my department has no record of any instance where an injunction was granted in circumstances that could be described as protests and boycott action by consumers, environmentalists, or human rights activists.

In relation to former sections 45D and 45E of the TPA prior to the commencement of the IRR Act in 1994, my department has records of nine cases where an injunction was granted in circumstances involving protests and boycott action that were taken by consumers environmentalists, or human rights activists. A list of these maters is attached.

My department has no record of injunctions being granted under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (WRA) in circumstances involving action by, environmentalists, consumer protection groups or human rights activists. The provisions of the WR Act authorising the issue of injunctions are concerned with various industrial maters (eg, enforcing orders made about industrial action, unfair and unlawful dismissal, and enforcing certain other provisions relating to industrial action, freedom of association, Australian Workplace Agreements, right of entry, strike pay, industrial election inquiries.)

(2) I have no record of any complaints that boycott provisions of the TPA or the WR Act have in any way stifled environmental, human rights, spiritual, cultural or consumer protest. The Assistant Treasurer has also advised that neither he nor the Treasurer has received any complaints that the TPA has stifled such protests.
Injunctions Granted under boycott provisionsâAttachment

entry.para: Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994.
Binalong Pty Ltd and Anor v Conservation Council of South Australia and Ors (1994) ATPR 41-312.

The case concerns both conservation and Aboriginal land rights issues. In late October 1993, the CFMEU and the Friends of Goolwa and Kumarangk (the Friends), placed pickets at the Hindmarsh Island Bridge construction site, obstructing the movement of a rode grader onto the site. After some days, attempts at construction ceased, and the picket was lifted. However, the CFMEU stated that should construction resume, the picket would be reinstated. The union also made public statements that it would never allow the bridge to be built, because its construction would result in environmental damage and interference to Aboriginal sites.

On 24 March 1994, an officer of the Conservation Council of South Australia gave a radio interview in which he asked Westpac, who was financing the project, to withdraw financial backing. Five days later, a public rally was held in opposition to the construction of the bridge. After the rally, members of the Union went to Westpac's office and handed a letter to an employee, again requesting that financial backing be withdrawn.

On 29 March 1994, Binalong Pty Ltd made an application under section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. That same day, the Federal Court granted interim injunctions restraining the respondents from hindering or preventing the construction of the bridge, and from hindering or preventing the provision of banking and/or financial services to the applicant by Westpac.

Heerey J (in a judgement delivered 19 April 1994), held that there was no triable issue in relation to the statements made by the Conservation Council. His Honour also held that an injunction should not be granted in relation to the approaches made to Westpac. However, he held that the CFMEU and the Friends had acted in concert to prevent building the bridge, which caused direct or obvious damage to the applicant's business. Accordingly, the interim injunction was replaced by an order restraining the CFMEU (and certain officers and members of the Union) and the Friends from hindering, preventing or attempting to hinder or prevent further construction.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994

In 1991, BHP Petroleum commenced action under section 45D against Greenpeace over the latter's disruption of BHP's seismic surveying operations off the Victorian coast. The area that the company was surveying contained the Southern Right Whale calving grounds. BHP Petroleum was granted an injunction preventing Greenpeace, its vessels or employees from approaching the survey vessel. After a public outcry, BHP did not pursue its action further.

It should be noted that this action, as it did not involve industrial action, would be covered by the defence in subsection 45DD(3) of the Trade Practice Act (as amended by Schedule 17 of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996.)
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Attorney-General of Queensland and Mary Kathleen Uranium v Seamen's Union of Australia Nos Q33 and Q32 of 1981

There were two cases concerning this issue, both arising out of the same set of circumstances. Bans were placed on ships (from 6/5/81) as part of the ACTU Uranium Boycott. The Attorney-General of Queensland and Mary Kathleen Uranium (MKU) made an application (22/10/81) under section 45D. An interim injunction was granted on 6/11/81.

The ACTU decided to defer the further implementation of its anti-uranium export policy in December 1981 (however, the MKU ships had sailed without uranium prior to this). Accordingly, the applications were withdrawn on 11/1 and 13/1/82.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Mary Kathleen Uranium v Waterside Workers' Federation and Anor No QG 25/1991
Mary Kathleen Uranium made another application against the WWF and AFSA (on 11/11/81). An interim injunction was issued the same day. The application was withdrawn on 25/8/82.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Air Pacific Limited v Transport Workers' Union No NG18/93

This matter arose from a dispute that Air Pacific was having in Fiji. Charges had been laid against the Secretary of the Fiji Airways Workers Association (FAWA) for strike action. On 13 January 1993, the Transport Workers' Union, acting in support of the FAWA, imposed bans on refuelling and baggage handling in respect of Air Pacific aircraft at Australian airports. On 15 January 1993, the company sought an ex parte interim injunction to restrain breaches of s.45D of the Act. An ex parte interlocutory injunction was granted on that day. This injunction was set aside on 23 January 1993. (It had been expressed to apply until 19.1.93, and the Transport Workers' Union had lifted its bans; however, due to the union's refusal to comply with subpoenas requiring the production of certain documents, Hill J amended the injunction so that it remained in force `until further order'.) The inunction was set aside after the parties had settled the dispute.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Overseas Containers Australia Pty Ltd v Seaman's Union of Australia No. G54/83

Regarding underpayment of crew members on a `flag or convenience' ship. Application made 23/3/83, interim injunction granted 24/3/83, matter adjourned indefinitely on 13/5/83 after a conference between ANL, maritime unions and the Minister for Transport.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Hamburg Suedameri-Kanische and Columbus Line v Seamen's Union of Australia No. G56/83
Regarding underpayment of crew members on a `flag of convenience' ship. Application made 23/2/83, interim injunction granted 24/3/83, matter adjourned indefinitely 10/6/83.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1994
Chevron Transport Corporation v Seamen's Union of Australia and Anor No. G230/83

Matter arose over underpayment on `flag of convenience' ship. Bans applied because crew members were paid below The International Transport Federation rate. Application made 15/8/83, interim injunction granted 17/8/83, bans lifted, matter adjourned indefinitely 19/8/83.
Trade Practices Act 1974, prior to 30 March 1974
Green Island Cement Pty Ltd v Waterside Workers' Federation and the Seamen's Union of Australia No. G463/84

Regarding underpayment of crew members. Application made 24/12/84, interim injunction granted 24/12/84. This led to the freezing of funds in the WWF bank account equivalent to those paid by Green Island to make up the underpayment to its employees. On 12/2/85, the application was withdrawn, with the company agreeing to pay all arrears.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 March 1998:

question.para: Given the serious problems associated with the Actual Means Test (AMT) for Austudy that were experienced throughout 1997, including the need for the Government to conduct a review of the AMT to identify anomalies in the test and apparently make improvements:

(1) Why, after significant time and resources have been spent "improving" the AMT process, does the situation currently exist that a person who was self-employed in 1996 and 1997 and earned around $30,000 per annum would receive virtually no Austudy upon undertaking full-time study for the first time in 1998, while a person who received a wage of $70,000 in 1997, in otherwise similar circumstances, would be entitled to the full rate of Austudy.

(2) Has the Department adopted a policy that students returning to study from the workforce will not generally be eligible for the current income concession, meaning that they will be tested on their 1996-97 income rather than 1997-98, thus potentially creating the farcical situation that even the AMT students whose only income in 1996-97 was from Austudy will receive a reduced Austudy entitlement in 1998.

(3) For how long has the Minister been aware of the serious inequities currently being experienced by independent students who are subject to the AMT, especially those who were self-employed before undertaking full-time study.
(4) What is being done by the Government to rectify this serious inequity, which may be preventing many of Australia's self-employed "battlers" from entering higher education.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1), (3) and (4) The Austudy student income test takes account of income earned by students in the period during which they are eligible to get Austudy. This is intended to reduce disincentives to earn income before they start to study. The actual means test is different. It was introduced to counter a perception in the community that undeserving families were able to manipulate their taxable income through complex financial arrangements and get Austudy while other, sometimes more needy, families could not. The previous Government considered that self-employed people should be subject to the actual means test because, for this group, the income tests may not be an adequate method of determining their need to share in the limited resources available for Austudy.

In most cases, actual means will be calculated on expenditure and savings in the last financial year before the year of study. For 1998, that is the 1996-97 financial year. This meets a major concern of public submissions to the 1997 Actual Means Test Review. A current actual means concession allows for actual means to be calculated on expenditure and savings in the financial year ending in the year of study. For 1998, that is the 1997-98 financial year.

I was advised in January 1998 that a small number of independent students who were self-employed in 1996-97 before undertaking full-time study in 1998 could have been disadvantaged by the 1998 actual means test because their actual means in 1996-97 (when they were self-employed) were higher than they were expected to be in 1997-98 (when they left their self-employment to study). Following detailed briefing from my Department, I agreed on 10 February 1998 to change the way the 1998 actual means test operates for self-employed people who leave their self-employment to take up full-time study.

From 1 January 1998, people who expect their actual means to fall substantially because of their decision to undertake full-time study may have their actual means calculated in the 1997-98 year rather than the 1996-97 year if the reduction is expected to last for at least two years. Furthermore, people who are no longer in a designated actual means test category, such as self-employment, may have their actual means calculated on their expenditure and savings in the 1997-98 year rather than the 1996-97 year if, as a result, there is a substantial reduction in their actual means that is expected to last for at least two years. I expect these changes to provide relief to the small number of students who may have been adversely affected by the 1998 actual means test.

(2) I assume that the Senator's question refers to the current actual means concession rather than the current income concession. Please refer to my answer to question 1 for details about how the concession operates.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: With reference to the `forced resignation in disgrace' of ex-Major Allan Warren:

(1) Is there any evidence to suggest that, in 1981, officers within the Transport Corp Directorate abused administrative procedures to force ex-Major Warren's resignation from the Australian Army; if so, what action is being taken; if not, what are the findings in the Minister's possession with regard to ex-Major Warren's forced resignation.

(2) Is the Minister aware of any investigations into, or information existing with regard to, the role of ex-Brigadier J A Hooper in the termination of ex-Major Warren's armed services career; if so, can details be provided of the history of any such investigations.

(3) (a) Can the Minister provide information on the several ministerial investigations carried out with regard to ex-Major Allan Warren's case between 1981 and 1994; (b) was any action required as a result of these investigations; if so, have these actions been carried out; if not, why not.

(4) Has correspondence been received from the Australian Army with regard to ex-Major Warren; if so, how has the Minister responded to the army's position on this matter, given the issues raised by ex-Major Warren in his correspondence.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIn accordance with advice to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel the following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There is no evidence to suggest that Army officers deliberately abused administrative procedures to force ex-Major Warren to resign. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal in 1993, and the investigation by Lieutenant Colonel B J Salmon QC in 1994, determined that ex-Major Warren was unfairly administered in respect of the termination of his appointment. An ex gratia payment was offered and was accepted by ex-Major Warren as compensation.

(2) There has been no investigation into ex-Brigadier Hooper's role in the termination of Ex-Major Warren's Army career. At the time of these events ex-Brigadier Hooper filled the appointment of Military Secretary. He held this position from 3 December 1979 until 10 December 1981. In performing the duties of his position he was responsible for the career management of all Regular Army officers. Ex-Brigadier Hooper was not the delegate who authorised the Notice to Show Cause why ex-Major Warren's appointment should not be terminated; this was done by the Chief of Personnel. He would, however, have provided the Chief of Personnel with information relating to ex- Major Warren's reported performance as an Army officer.

(3) (a) and (b) The other major issues raised by ex-Major Warren in his ministerial representations relate to the preparation of his annual confidential reports and the scoring of them. These issues were dealt with by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in 1993 which found that statements made in some confidential reports and letters were incomplete or misleading and did not constitute an objective report of ex-Major Warren. On direction by the Tribunal, relevant documents on ex-Major Warren's dossier were annotated accordingly. The Tribunal found that there was no unfair, misleading or improper Defence administration in the scoring applied to ex-Major Warren's annual reports. In 1994 Lieutenant Colonel B J Salmon QC was engaged to further investigate the matter of the Army scoring system. He confirmed that no improper procedures were used in scoring the confidential reports.
(4) Correspondence from the Army is in the standard form of briefs accompanying suggested responses to Ministerial representations by or on behalf of ex-Major Warren.

The Department of Defence has acknowledged, and regrets, that there was unfair administration by Army in relation to ex-Major Warren. An ex gratia payment has been made to, and accepted by ex-Major Warren, in compensation. His personal file has been annotated to record the findings of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
