talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 17 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Who has responsibility for independently auditing the departments of the House of Representatives, the Senate and Joint House.
(2) Who has responsibility for independently auditing members and electorate office expenditure, and senators and electorate office expenditure.
(3) Who has responsibility for independently auditing the offices of Ministers of State.
(4) Who has responsibility for independently auditing expenditure under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984.

(5) Are any of the stated offices or departments independently audited in terms of financial statements audits, which include efficiency audits and project performance audits, (in each case, distinguish between regular audit processes and by arrangement or occasional audits and provide details of the reporting details on audits undertaken).
(6) Who has authority to undertake and order audits of expenditure by: (a) ministers and ministers staff; and (b) parliamentarians and parliamentarian staff.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Auditor-General is responsible for auditing the parliamentary departments.

(2) The Auditor-General's financial statement audit responsibilities encompass expenditure of public moneys incurred by Members and Senators, including electorate office expenditure, as that expenditure relates to, and is reported in, departmental financial statements. Expenditure by Members and Senators could also be audited in the context of a performance audit by the Auditor-General of the administration of the agency from whose annual appropriation this expenditure is incurred.

(3) The Auditor-General has responsibility for auditing the payment of public moneys to Ministers' offices, but it is a matter for each Minister to determine the way in which he or she operates his or her office. The scope of the Auditor-General's financial statement audit responsibili ties also encompass expenditure incurred by a Minister which is included in an agency's financial statements.

(4) The Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 (MOPS Act) does not appropriate moneys for expenditure. Expenditure that arises as a result of appointments made in accordance with the MOPS Act is met from annual appropriations of the Department of Finance and Administration. The Auditor-General is responsible for auditing expenditure made by the Department under those appropriations. However, the Auditor-General Act 1997 specifically excludes the activities of people employed under the MOPS Act from the Auditor-General's performance audit mandate.

(5) The Auditor-General may conduct audits of the financial statements and performance of Commonwealth agencies including the departments of the Parliament. In addition, the Auditor-General may, by arrangement with any person or body, undertake financial statements audits, conduct performance audits or provide services of a kind normally performed by auditors. The reporting arrangements for those audits would be determined as part of the arrangement entered into between the Auditor-General and the person or body. More generally, the Auditor-General may report to the Parliament on any matter at any time.

(6) The Auditor-General has authority to undertake audits of expenditure from money appropriated by the Parliament as set out in the answers to questions (1), (2) and (3). The Auditor-General, in determining what matters are to be audited, will have regard to the audit priorities of the Parliament as determined by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. However, under the Auditor-General Act 1997, the Auditor-General is not subject to direction from anyone in relation to: (a) whether or not a particular audit is to be conducted; or (b) the way in which a particular audit is to be conducted; or (c) the priority to be given to any particular matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) How does the Veterans' Vehicle Assistance Scheme work; and (b) what are the eligibility requirements for the scheme.
(2) What assistance is available under the scheme, for example, can it cover the cost of accessories fitted to vehicles for those who require them and does it cover the dealer delivery fees.

(3) Is relief from sales tax provided under the scheme; if so: (a) does this apply to all veterans; and (b) does the veteran pay sales tax and have it refunded or is the sales tax not added to the purchase price by the vehicle dealer.
(4) How do discounts or special offers provided by vehicle dealers or manufacturers affect the assistance provided under the scheme.
(5) Can examples be provided which show how the final cost of the vehicle is calculated and also show the level of assistance that is provided through the scheme.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Vehicle Assistance Scheme provides veterans who are suffering from severe service-related mobility impairment with a grant to purchase a suitable motor vehicle with the appropriate driving devices, a yearly allowance to assist with the running and maintenance of the vehicle, and a further grant available every two years to assist with replacing the vehicle.
(b) A veteran is eligible for assistance under the scheme if the veteran is incapacitated from war-caused injury or war-caused disease by reason of:
. amputation of both legs above the knee;

. amputation of one leg above the knee and, in addition: (i) amputation of the other leg at or above the ankle and amputation of one arm at or above the wrist; or (ii) amputation of both arms at or above the wrists;
. complete paraplegia resulting in the total loss of voluntary power in both legs to the extent that there is insufficient power for purposeful use for stance or locomotion; or
. a condition that, in the opinion of the Repatriation Commission, is similar in effect or severity to the amputations described in the first two dot points.
A leg that has been rendered permanently and wholly useless above the knee is treated as if it had been amputated above the knee.

In addition to the eligibility criteria based on mobility impairment, a current driver's licence must be held by the veteran, or the veteran's partner, or the veteran's carer. If the veteran is unable to drive a vehicle, he or she must have the capacity of being readily transported in the vehicle.

(2) The scheme provides an initial grant to purchase a motor vehicle, a yearly allowance to assist with the running and maintenance of the vehicle and a further grant available every two years to assist with replacing the vehicle. If a veteran requires driving devices to enable him or her to drive the vehicle, these are fitted with no additional cost to the veteran. Modifications such as ramps, removal of seats to accommodate a wheelchair, hoists etc may also be provided at no cost to the veteran if they are necessary to enable the veteran to derive benefit from the vehicle.
No separate provision is made for dealer delivery fees. These costs are included in the grant amounts.

(3) (a) Yes. Any veteran who is within the scheme has relief from sales tax. Other veterans, such as veterans who are classified as Totally and Permanently Incapacitated (TPI) or certain amputees who do not meet the medical eligibility for the scheme may also have relief from sales tax under Item 96 in Schedule 1 of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1922.
(b) An eligible veteran does not pay sales tax and it is not added to the purchase price.

(4) As payment is made direct to vehicle dealers, only the actual purchase price is considered in the grant. Vehicle dealers are required to complete a statement showing any discounts or offers which affect the recommended retail price.

(5) Yes. The maximum grant towards an initial motor vehicle provided under the scheme is based on the higher recommended retail price (less sales tax) of a Ford or Holden automatic station wagon fitted with air conditioning, dual air-bags, anti-lock braking system, electric windows and cruise control.

The current benchmark value for an initial vehicle is $31, 923. It is based on a Holden "Acclaim" vehicle fitted with the extras. While a veteran may purchase an initial motor vehicle in excess of the benchmark value, any amount over and above this value is generally the responsibility of the veteran.

However, if the Repatriation Commission is satisfied that the nature of the veteran's incapacity from a war-caused condition is such that the provision of a more expensive vehicle is necessary, it may authorise payment of part or whole of the difference in cost between the authorised maximum value and the actual purchase price of the vehicle.
A replacement grant is available at two year intervals to contribute towards the replacement of a motor vehicle provided for, or contributed to, by the Scheme.

The maximum replacement grant (MRG) is calculated as the difference between the benchmark value (BV) and the recommended value (RV) of the vehicle being exchanged. The RV used is that published in the current industry guide on the value of used vehicles (Glass' Passenger Vehicle Guide). So the formula is MRG = BVâRV. The value of a replacement grant cannot exceed the value of the maximum replacement grant.
The actual replacement grant, i.e. the grant actually paid, is the lesser of the maximum replacement grant and the value either:
. cited by the motor dealer on the Dealer Statement as the exchange value in the event of a trade-in; or
. calculated by subtracting the value the veteran received in a private sale from the benchmark value.
The veteran's statement to this effect is included in the Application Form. Either of these statements must be completed and signed by the appropriate party before a replacement grant is approved.

For example: A veteran applies for assistance under the scheme. After the veteran is assessed as eligible he orders a new vehicle from a dealer. The recommended retail price of the vehicle (less sales tax) is $35,000. As the initial grant has a benchmark value of $31,923 the veteran is required to make up the $3,077 difference as no special circumstances apply.

After two years, the veteran decides to trade in the vehicle with a dealer for a new vehicle which has a recommended retail price of $33,500. According to Glass's Guide, the veteran's vehicle has a recommended value (RV) of $22,000. The maximum of the replacement grant cannot exceed $9,923. This is calculated by subtracting the recommended value from the benchmark value, i.e. $31,923 less $22,000.

The dealer, however, discounts the new vehicle by $1,500 which makes the actual cost of the new car $32,000. The veteran is offered a trade-in of $22,500, making the exchange value $9,500. As this amount is less than the maximum replacement grant, $9,500 becomes the value of the grant paid to the veteran to replace his or her vehicle.

Generally, the maximum replacement grant is not expected to be more than $16,000. In extreme cases, the Repatriation Commission can authorise a greater amount if, in all the circumstances of the case, it is considered necessary.
A yearly in advance grant of $780 is available to an eligible veteran under the Vehicle Assistance Scheme to assist with the running and maintenance of the vehicle.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 March 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) What internal or external surveys, research or other forms of information has been gathered on the accuracy of recording cancellations resulting from data matching review activities; (b) what were the findings of any such activities; and (c) what percentage of the recording of `cancellations' from data matching review activities were found to be incorrect.

(2) (a) What internal or external surveys, research or other forms of information has been gathered on the accuracy of recording cancellations resulting from employment declaration form review activities; (b) what were the findings of any such activities; and (c) what percentage of the recording of `cancellations' from employment declaration form review activities were found to be incorrect.

(3) (a) What internal or external surveys, research or other forms of information has been gathered on the accuracy of recording cancellations resulting from any other review activities; (b) what were the findings of any such activities; and (c) what percentage of the recording of `cancellations' from any other review activities were found to be incorrect.
(4) What is regarded as the maximum acceptable level of statistical error in recording cancellations from review activities.
(5) How do the above findings affect the accuracy of the quarterly compliance reports tabled in Parliament by the minister.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Area level `best practice' examinations relating to Employment Declaration Form (EDF) review activity, plus the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) and other review checks mentioned in the answers to parts (2) and (3) below.

(2) (a)Examinations of EDF review work has been undertaken at an individual Area Support Office level with the aim of identifying the application of best practices and assessing the appropriateness of result recording.

External checking of all review activities has been undertaken by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) for the purpose of annual financial statements. The ANAO re-tests a sample of completed reviews to ensure that the level of error in decision-making is acceptable and that the results of the reviews can be relied on.

(2) (b) For the 1996-97 financial year, the ANAO concluded that the review process was satisfactory, providing adequate controls over the validity of income support payments for financial statement audit purposes.

As an integral component of its normal administration, Centrelink has ongoing measures in place to ensure the accuracy of the recording of customer information on its systems. This is facilitated by checking a minimum 10% random sample of all determinations by a second officer through the Procedure and Accuracy Checking (PAC) system. PAC monitoring since April 1997 has shown an accuracy rate for all review work of between 97% and 98%. It must be emphasised that this apparent 2%-3% `error rate' covers a variety of administrative shortcomings, not just those relating to the coding of payment cancellations. Review coordinators at all levels of Centrelink continually monitor the quality and appropriateness of review work, correct mistakes found and arrange for the on-going training of staff.

(2) (c) The Area by Area EDF `best practice' examinations identified a total of some 517 cancellations as having been inappropriately recorded in some way, including cases involving inadequate documentation by staff rather than an incorrectly claimed result. Action has been taken on Centrelink's review system to amend any inappropriate results and staff advised of the correct procedures to follow in the future. Statistically valid national outcomes cannot be drawn from these Area based `best practice' examinations.
(3) (a) Other on-going review activity is subject to the same level of checking and monitoring as described in the answer to part (2) (b) above.

(3) (b) As noted previously, as part of day to day operation, adjustments are continually being made to records on Centrelink's review system to ensure it presents the most accurate picture available of review results. Any review entries which are deleted or amended as a result of this process are either excluded from or appropriately adjusted in terms of reported results.

(4) Centrelink does not work to a maximum acceptable level of statistical error in its recording activities. We are aware, however, that the ANAO generally regard statistical errors in excess of 5% as material.

(5) As noted above, it is normal practice for Centrelink to continually remove or adjust any inappropriate review recording system entries identified before results are reported. Notwithstanding this practice, even if all previously identified inappropriate entries had been included, the quantum of them is not such as to adversely impact on the overall accuracy of the quarterly compliance reports tabled in Parliament.

answer.para: (1) I do not recall discussing this matter with the Member for Page, Mr Causley.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 30 March 1998:

question.para: With reference to the article `Elizabeth Creek hailed as new Century' in the Australian of 24 March 1998:

(1) (a) Which indigenous groups have been consulted about the Elizabeth Creek prospect and the exploration permit application process; (b) when were those consultations held; and (c) what was the outcome.

(2) Will any successful explorer or deposit-exploiter be required, according to the user-pays principle, to pay for that component of the $4 million mapping project relating to the region and any other public costs incurred.
(3) What environmental, social or economic studies have been done on the potential impact of exploration or mining in this area.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (3) are matters for the Queensland Government.

(2) The National Geoscience Mapping Accord (NGMA) is a co-operative program of geoscience mapping between the States and Commonwealth which was established by the Australian and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council (ANZMEC) in 1990. The rationale for the Accord is the need to renew the national geoscience infrastructure by a program of modern geoscience mapping to aid sustainable development and resource exploration into the next century.
The objectives of the Accord are to:
. Encourage energy and mineral resource exploration in Australia.
. Help make exploration in Australia more cost effective.
. Assist responsible resource and environmental management.
Geoscientific studies in the North Australian Basins Resource Evaluation project (NABRE) commenced in 1995. This NGMA project is designed to influence the economic development of Northern Australia.

NABRE aims to provide exploration companies with a state-of-the-art regional overview of the geological evolution of this part of northern Australia, the type of study necessary to increase the probability of discovering additional metal and energy resources in the area. NABRE is a co-operative initiative of the Commonwealth Government, the Queensland and Northern Territory Governments and includes collaborative studies with university and mineral industry geoscientists.

Outputs from the NABRE project will be available to Australian and overseas exploration companies, Government, University researchers and the general public. Products are not sold on a cost recovery basis. However, money invested by the Commonwealth and State Governments is recovered several times over by the generation of interest in new exploration. Over the next year the NABRE project is scheduled to produce both digital and hard copy datasets all with the aim of reducing exploration risk and assisting the process of sound land use management in this area. The data package accompanying the Elizabeth Creek Prospect represents one of these products.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Given that nine departments have now answered in full the questions placed on notice on 16 October 1997 (questions on notice 902-916, Senate Notice Paper of 21 October 1997) relating to qualitative and quantitative research, on what basis was it decided that the department would not authorise the money, time and effort involved to assemble the information required to provide an answer to the question.
(2) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(3) (a) What was the nature of the research undertaken, (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation); and (b) to whom were the results of the research available.
(4) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(5) In each instance what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (5) In my answer to the Senator's original question on notice of 16 October (No 908), I indicated that I was not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money, time and effort to assemble the information required to answer the question. This was my decision rather than my Department's.

My decision was based on the scope of the question and, in particular, the timeframe which covers a large volume of research activity, including a period of some 15 months before the establishment of Centrelink. In addition, to answer part (2) of the question would have required the collation of a large amount of detailed information. My decision also took account of the fact that successive annual reports of the Department of Social Security contain detailed information on non-training research undertaken by consultants.
